editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE WIDDOW A COMEDIE. As it was Acted at the private Houſe in Black-Fryers, with great Applauſe, by His late MAJESTIES Servants.

Written by
BEN: JOHNSON. Gent.
JOHN FLETCHER. Gent.
THO: MIDDLETON. Gent.
LONDON, Printed for Humphrey Moſeley and are to be Sold at his Shop, at the Sign of the Princes Arms in St. Pauls Church-yard. 1652.

div.head: To the Reader.
div.p: COnſidering how the curious pay ſome part of their eſteem to excellent perſons in the carefull preſervation but of their defaced ſtatues, inſtead of decayed medals of the Romans greatneſs, I believed it of more value to preſent you this lively piece, drawn by the art of Johnſon, Fletcher, and Middleton, which is thought to have a neer reſemblance to the portracture we have in Terence of thoſe worthy minds, where the great Scipio and Laelius ſtrove to twiſt the Poets Ivy with the victors Bayes. As the one was deſerv'd by their work in ſubduing their Countries enemies, ſo the other, by their recreation and delight which was to baniſh that folly and ſadneſs, that were worſe than Haniball, or all the monſters and venome of Africa. Since our own Countrymen are not in any thing inferior, It were to be wiſhed, they had but ſo much incouragement, that the paſt licence and abuſes charged on the Stage, might not ever be thought too unpardonable to paſs in oblivion, and ſo good Laws and inſtructions for manners uncapable of being regulated, which if but according to this pattern, certainly none need think himſelf the leſs a good Chriſtian for owning the ſame deſire as

list.item: 2 Old men Suters to the Widdow.
RICARDO, A decayed young Gent. and Suter to the Widdow.
MARTIA, Daughter to one of the old Suters and ſuppoſed a man.

div.head: Actus 1. Scoena 1.
div.stage: Enter Signior MARTINO (an old Juſtices Clerk) and FRANCISCO.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: MArtino?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Signior Franciſco? y'ar the luckieſt Gentleman to meet
Or ſee firſt in a morning: I never ſaw you yet
But I was ſure of money within leſs than half an hour.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I bring you the ſame luck ſtill.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What you doe not?
I hope Sir you are not come for an other Warrant?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Yes faith, for an other Warrant.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Why ther's my dream come out then. I never dream'd of a buttock but I was ſure to have money for a Warrant. It is the luckieſt part of all the body to me: let every man ſpeak as he finds. Now your Uſurer is of opinion, that to dream of the Devill is your wealthier dream; and I think if a man dream of that part that brings many to the Devill, 'tis as good; and has all one ſmatch indeed; for if one be the fleſh, th'others the
broth: So 'tis in all his members and we mark it; if Gluttony be the meat, Leachery is the Porredge, they'r both boyld together, and wee Clerks will have our modicum too, though it conclude in the two penny chop: Why Sir, Signior Franciſco.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: 'Twas her voice ſure,
Or my ſoul takes delight to think it was,
And makes a ſound like hers.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sir, I beſeech you.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: It is the prettieſt contriv'd building, this:
What Poeſie's that I prethee?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Which Sir, that
Under the great braſs Squirt?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I that Sir, that

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: From fire, from water, and all things amiſs,
Deliver the houſe of an honeſt Juſtice?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Ther's like to be a good houſe kept then, when fire and water's forbidden to come into the Kitchin. Not yet a ſight of hir? this hour's unfortunate. And what's that yonder prethee? O loves famine, Ther's no affliction like thee. I, I hear you Sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Y'ar quicker ear'd than I then: you hear me
Before I heard my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: A gift in friendſhip
Some call it an inſtinct.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It may be
Th' other's the ſweeter phraſe though; Look you Sir,
Mine own wit this, and 'tis as true as turtle;
A Gooſe-quill and a Clerk, a Conſtable and a Lanthorn,
Brings many a Baud from Coach to Cart, and many a Thief to one turn.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: That one turn helpt you well.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
'Tas helpt me to money indeed for many a Warrant. I am 40. dollars the better for that one-turn; and 'twould come off quicker 'twer nere a whit the worſe for me. But indeed when Thieves are taken, and break away twice or thrice one after an other, ther's my gains; then goes out more Warrants to fetch'em agen: one fine nimble villain, may be worth a man ten dollars in and out a that faſhion; I love ſuch a one with my heart, I, and
will help him to ſcape to, and I can; hear you me that: Ile have him in at all times at a months warning: nay, ſay I let him run like a Summer Nag all the Vacation: See you theſe blancks, Ile ſend him but one of theſe bridles, and bring him in at Michaelmas with a vengeance: nothing kils my heart, but when one of 'em dyes Sir; then ther's no hope of more money: I had rather loſe at all times two of my beſt kindred, than an excellent Thief: for hee's a Gentleman I'm more beholding to.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: You betray your myſtery too much Sir. Yet no comfort?
'Tis but her ſight that I waſte precious time for,
For more I cannot hope for, ſhe's ſo ſtrict,
Yet that I cannot have.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I'm ready now Signior.

div.p: Here are blanck Warrants of all diſpoſitions, give me but the name and nature of your Malefactor, and Ile beſtow him according to his merits.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: This only is th' excuſe that bears me out,
And keeps off impudence and ſuſpition
From my too frequent comming: what name now
Shall I think on, and not to wrong the houſe?
This Coxcomb wilbe prating.—One Aſtilio,
His offence wilfull murder.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Wilfull murder? oh I love a life to have ſuch a fellow come under my fingers; like a begger that's long a taking leave of a fat lowce, I'm loth to part with him, I muſt look upon him over and over firſt; are you wilfull? y'faith, ile be as wilfull as you then.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Martino?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Miſtriſſe?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Make haſte, your Maſter's going.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I'm but about a wilfull murder forſooth, Ile diſpatch that preſently.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Good morrow Sir: oh that I durſt ſaymore.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: 'Tis gone agen, ſince; ſuch are all lifes pleaſures,
No ſooner known, but loſt; he that enjoys 'em
The length of life, has but a longer dream,
He wakes to this i'th end, and ſees all nothing.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: He cannot ſee me now; ile mark him better
Before I be too raſh: ſweetly compos'd he is;
Now as he ſtands, he's worth a womans love,
That loves only for ſhape, as moſt on's doe:
But I muſt have him wiſe, as well as proper,
He comes not in my Books elſe, and indeed
I have thought upon a courſe to try his wit: Violetta.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Miſtriſſe.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Yonders the Gentleman agen.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Oh ſweet Miſtriſſe
Pray give me leave to ſee him.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nay take heed,
Open not the window and you love me.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: No, I've the view of whole body here, Miſtriſſe,
At this pore little ſlit, oh enough, enough,
In troth 'tis a fine out-ſide.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I ſee that.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Has curld his hair moſt judiciouſly well.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I ther's thy love, now, it begins in barbariſm: ſhe buys a Gooſe with feathers, that loves a Gentleman for's hair; ſhe may be cozend to her face Wench. Away: he takes his leave. Reach me that letter hither, quick▪ quick Wench.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nay look upon't, and ſpare not: every one cannot get that kind of Warrant from me Signior. Doe you ſee this prick i'th bottom, it betokens powr and ſpeed, it is a privy mark, that runs betwixt the Conſtables and my Mr. Thoſe that cannot read, when they ſee this, know 'tis for Leacherie or Murder, and this being away, the Warrant comes gelded, and inſufficient.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I thank you Sir,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Look you; all theſe are Nihils,
They want the punction.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Yes, I ſee they doe Sir,
Ther's for thy pains, mine muſt goe unrewarded.
The better love, the worſe by fate regarded.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Well, goe thy wayes, for the ſweeteſt Coſtomer that ever Penman was bleſt withall: now will he come for an other to morrow agen; if he hold on this courſe, he will leave never a knave i'th town within this twelve month: no matter, I ſhalbe rich enough by that time.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Martino?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Say you forſooth.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What paper's that the Gentleman let fall there?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l:
Paper? Tis the Warrant I hope, if it be ile hide it, and
make him pay for't agen. No Pox: 'tis not ſo happy.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What i'ſt Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Tis nothing but a letter forſooth.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Is that nothing?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Nothing, in reſpect of a Warrant Miſtriſs.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: A letter? why 'tas been many a mans undoing Sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: So has a Warrant, and you goe to that Miſtriſs.

sp.speaker: Phil,
sp.l: Read but the ſuperſcription; and away with't:
Alas it may concern the Gentleman neerly.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why Miſtriſs, this letter is at home already.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: At home, how mean your Sir?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You ſhall hear Miſtriſs. To the deſervingſt of all her Sex, and moſt worthie of his beſt reſpect and love, Mrs. Philippa Brandino.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How Sir, to me?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: To you Miſtriſs.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Run, as thou lov'ſt my honour, and thy life,
Call him agen, Ile not endure this injury:
But ſtay, ſtay now I think on't, 'tis my credit,
Ile have your Maſters Counſell: ah baſe fellow
To leave his looſe lines thus; 'tis even as much
As a poor honeſt Gentlewomans undoing,
Had I not a grave wiſeman to my Husband:
And thou a vigilant varlet to admit
Thou car'ſt not whom

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Las 'tis my office Miſtriſs.
You know you have a Kirtle every year,
And 'tis within two months of the time now,
sp.p: The velvets comming over: pray be milder; a man that has a place muſt take money of any body: pleaſe you to throw me down but half a dollar, and Ile make you a warrant for him now, that's all I care for him.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Well, look you be cleer now from this foul conſpiracie
Againſt mine honour; or your Maſters love to you
That makes you ſtout, ſhall not maintain you here;
It ſhall not: truſt to 't.— Exit.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: This is ſtrange to me now:
Dare ſhe doe this, and but eight weeks to New-years tide?
A man that had his blood as hot as hers now, would fit her with
French Velvet: Ile goe neer it.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: If this be a wrong to modeſt reputation
Be you the cenſurer Sir, that are the Maſter
Both of your fame and mine.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Signior Franciſco?
Ile make him fly the land.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: That will be hard Sir;
I think he be not ſo well feather'd Maſter,
H'as ſpent the beſt part of his patrimonie.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Hark of his bold confederate.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: There thour't bitter;
And I muſt chide thee now.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What ſhould I think Sir?
He comes to your man for Warrants.

sp.speaker: Brand.
sp.l: There it goes then;
Come hither knave: Comes he to you for Warrants?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why, what of that Sir?
You know I give no Warrants to make Cuckolds,
That comes by fortune, and by nature Sir.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: True, that comes by fortune, and by nature; Wife
Why do'ſt thou wrong this man?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: He needs no Warrant Maſter, that goes about ſuch buſineſs, a Cuckold-maker carrys always his warrant about him.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: La: has he anſwered well now? to the full?
What cauſe haſt thou t' abuſe him?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Hear me out I pray:
Through his admittance, h'as had opportunitie
To come into the houſe, and court me bodly.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Sirrah, y'ar foul agen me thinks.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Who I Sir?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: You gave this man admittance intoth'houſe.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: That's true Sir, you never gave me any order yet
To write my Warrants ith' ſtreet.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Why ſure thou tak'ſt delight to wrong this fellow, Wife:
Hah, cauſe I love him.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Pray ſee the fruits: ſee what has left behind here:
Be angry where you ſhould be: there's few Wives
Would doe as I doe

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Nay Ile ſay that for thee
I ne'r found thee but honeſt.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: She's a beaſt
That ever was found otherwayes.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Read Martino,
Mine eyes are ſore already, and ſuch buſineſs
Would put'em out quite

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Fair, dear and incomparable Miſtriſſe,—

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Oh! every letter draws a tooth me thinks.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And it leads mine to watring.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Here's no villanie?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: My love being ſo violent, and the opportunitie ſo pretious in your husbands abſence to night, who as I underſtand takes a journy this morning.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Oh plot of villany.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Am I honeſt think you Sir?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Exactly honeſt, perfectly improov'd: on, on Martino.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I will make bold dear Miſtreſſe, though your chaſtity has given me many a repulſe, to wait the ſweet bleſſings of this long deſired opportunitie, at the back gate, between nine and ten this night.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: I feel this Ins-a-Court man in my Temples.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Where if your affection bee pleas'd to receive me, you receive the faithfulleſt that ever vow'd ſervice to woman—Franciſco.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: I will make Franciſco ſmart for't.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Shew him the letter, let him know, you know him;
That will torment him: all your other courſes
Are nothing Sir to that: that breaks his heart.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: The ſtrings ſhall not hold long then: Come Martino.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Now if Franciſco have any wit at all,
He comes at night; if not, he never ſhall.

div.head: Scoena. 2.
div.stage: Enter FRANCISCO and RICARDO and ATTILIO.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Nay mark, mark it Franciſco: It was the naturaleſt curteſie that ever was ordaind; A young Gentleman being ſpent, to have a rich Widow ſet him up agen: to ſee how fortune has provided for all mortalities ruins; your College for your old ſtanding Scholer, your Hoſpitall for your lame creeping Souldier, your Baud for your mangled Rorer, your open houſe for your Beggar, and your Widow for your Gentleman: ha Franciſco?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I Sir, you may be merry: you'r in hope of a rich Widow.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: And why ſhouldſt not thou be in hope of an other, if there were any ſpirit in thee, thou art as likely a fellow as any is in the company. Ile be hang'd now if I doe not hit the true cauſe of thy ſadneſs; and confeſs truly y'faith; thou haſt ſome land unſold yet, I hold my life.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Mary I hope ſo Sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: A Pox ont, have I found it? 'slight away with't with all ſpeed man. I was never merry at heart while I had a foot: why man, Fortune never minds us, till we are left alone to our ſelves: for what need ſhe take care for them, that doe nothing but take care for themſelves? why, do'ſt think if I had kept my lands ſtill, I ſhould ever have look'd after a rich Widow? alas, I ſhould have married ſome poor young Maid, got five and twenty children, and undone my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: I proteſt Sir, I ſhould not have the face though, to come to a rich Widow with nothing

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Why, art thou ſo ſimple, as thou mak'ſt thy ſelf? do'ſt think y'faith I come to a rich Widow with nothing?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I mean with ſtate not anſwerable to hers.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Why ther's the fortune, man, that I talkd on;
She knows all this, and yet I am welcome to her.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I▪ that's ſtrange Sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Nay more to pierce thy hard heart, and make thee ſell thy land if thou'ſt any grace: ſhe has 'mongſt others two ſubſtantiall Suters,
sp.l: One, in good time bee't ſpoke, I owe much money to,
She knows this too, and yet I'm welcome to her,
Nor dares the unconſcionable Raſcall trouble me;
Sh'as told him thus, thoſe that profeſs love to her
Shall have the libertie to come and goe,
Or elſe get him gone firſt; ſhe knows not yet
Where fortune may beſtow her, ſhe's her gift,
Therefore to all will ſhew a kind reſpect.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Why this is like a woman: I ha' no luck in't.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: And as at a Sheriffs table, O bleſt cuſtome,
A poor indebted Gentleman may dine,
Feed well, and without fear, and depart ſo,
So to her lips, fearleſs I come and goe?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: You may well boaſt, y'ar much the happier man Sir

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: So you would be, and you would ſell your land Sir

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I have heard the circumſtance of your ſweet fortunes:
Prethee give ear to my unlucky tale now.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: That's an ill hearing; but come on for once Sir.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I never yet lov'd but one Woman.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Right, I begun ſo too; but I have lov'd a thouſand ſince.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Pray hear me Sir; but this is a mans wife.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: So has five hundred of my thouſand been.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Nay ſee and you'l regard me.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: No? you ſee I doe,
I bring you an example in for every thing.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: This mans wife

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: So you ſaid.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Seems very ſtrict

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Ha, humh.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Doe you laugh at that?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Seems very ſtrict you ſaid,
I hear you man, y'faith you are ſo jealous ſtill.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: But why ſhould that make you laugh?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Becauſe ſhe ſeems ſo: you'r ſuch an other—

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Nay Sir, I think ſhe is.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: You cannot tell then.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I dare not aske the queſtion I proteſt
For fear of a repulſe, which yet not having.
My mind's the quieter, and I live in hope ſtill.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Ha, hum: this 'tis to be a landed man. Come, I perceive
I muſt ſhow you a little of my fortune, and inſtruct you:
Not aske the queſtion?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Me thought ſtill ſhe fround Sir?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Why that's the cauſe fool, that ſhe look'd ſo ſcurvily.
Come, come, make me your woman, you'l ne'r do't elſe,
Ile ſhew you her condition preſently.
sp.p: I perceive you muſt begin like a young Vaulter, and get up at horſe-tail, before you get into the ſaddle; have you the boldneſs to utter your mind to me now, being but in hoſe and doublet? I think if I ſhould put on a Farthingale, thou wouldeſt never have the heart to do't.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Perhaps I ſhould not then for laughing at you Sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: In the mean time I fear I ſhall laugh at thee without one.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Nay you muſt think friend, I dare ſpeak to a woman.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: You ſhall pardon me for that friend; I will not think it,
till I ſee't.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Why you ſhall then: I ſhalbe glad to learn too, Of one ſo deep as you are.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: So you may Sir; Now 'tis my beſt courſe to look mildly, I ſhall put him out at firſt elſe.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: A word, ſweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: With me Sir? ſay your pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: O Ricardo,
Thou art too good to be a woman long.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Doe not find fault with this, for fear I prove
Too ſcornfull, be content when y'ar well us'd.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: You ſay well Sir. Lady I have lov'd you long.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: 'Tis a good hearing Sir. If he be not out now ile be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: You play a ſcornefull woman? I perceive Ricardo, You have not been us'd to 'em: why ile come in at my pleaſure with you: alas 'tis nothing for a man to talk, when a woman gives way too't: one ſhall ſeldome meet with a Lady ſo kind, as thou playdſt her.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Not altogether perhaps: he that draws their pictures muſt ſlatter 'em a little, they'l look he that plays 'em ſhould doo't a great deal then.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Come, come ile play the woman, that I'm us'd too,
I ſee you ne'r wore ſhooe that pincht you yet,
All your things comes on eaſie.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Say you ſo Sir?
Ile try your Ladiſhip 'faith: Lady well met.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I doe not think ſo Sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: A ſcornefull Gom,
sp.p: And at the firſt daſh too: my Widow never gave me ſuch an anſwer, ile to you agen Sir.
sp.l: Faireſt of creatures, I doe love thee infinitely.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Ther's no body bids you Sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Pox on thee thou art the beaſtlieſt croſſeſt Baggage that ever man met withall; but ile ſee thee hang'd ſweet Lady ere I be daunted with this: why thou'rt too awkward Sirha.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Hang thee baſe fellow.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Now by this light, he thinks he do'ſt indeed,
Nay then have at your plumb-tree faith, ile not be foild,
sp.p: Though you ſeem to be careleſs Madam, as you have enough wherwith all to be, yet I doe, muſt, and will love you.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Sir, if you begin to be rude, ile call my woman.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: What a peſtilent Queans this? I ſhall have much adoe with her I ſee that; tell me as y'ar a woman Lady, what ſerve kiſſes for? but to ſtop all your mouths.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Hold, hold Ricardo.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Diſgrace me VVidow.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Ait mad, I'm Franciſco?

sp.speaker: Atta.
sp.l: Signior Ricardo, up, up.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: VVho is't Franciſco?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Franciſco quoth a? what are you mad Sit?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: A bots on thee, thou do'ſt not know what injury thou haſt done me, I was i'th' faireſt dream, this is your way now, and you can follow it.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: 'Tis a ſtrange way me thinks.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Learn you to play a woman not ſo ſcornfully then,
For I am like the Actor that you ſpoke on,
I muſt have the part that overcomes the Lady,
I never like the Play elſe.—Now your friendſhip,
But to aſſiſt a ſubtle trick I ha' thought on,
And the rich VVidows mine within theſe three hours.

sp.speaker: Att. Fra.
sp.l: VVe ſhould be proud of that Sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Liſt to me then.
Ile place you too, I can do't handſomly
I know the houſe ſo well, to hear the conference
'Twixt her and I, ſhe's a moſt affable one,
Her words will give advantage, and ile urge 'em
To the kind proof, to catch her in a Contract,
Then ſhall you both ſtep in as witneſſes,
And take her in the ſnare.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: But doe you love hir?
And then 'twill proſper.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: By this hand I doe,
Not for her wealth, but for her perſon too.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: It ſhalbe done then.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: But ſtay, ſtay Franciſco,
Where ſhall we meet with thee ſome two hours hence now?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Why hark you Sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Enough, command my life,
Get me the widow, ile get thee the wife.

sp.speaker: Fra
sp.l: Oh that's now with me paſt hope; yet I muſt love her,
I would I could not do't.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yonder's the villain Maſter.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Franciſco; I am happy.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Let's both draw Mr. for ther's no body with him; Stay, ſtay Mr.
sp.l: Doe not you draw till I be ready too,
Let's draw juſt both together, and keep ev'n.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: What and we kill'd him now, before he ſaw us?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No, then he will hardly ſee to read the letter.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: That's true: good counſell marry.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Marry thus much Sir, You may kill him lawfully, all the while he's a reading on't, as an Anabaptiſt may lie with a Brothers wife, all the while he's a ſleep.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: He turns; he looks: Come on Sir, you, Franciſco,
I lov'd your father well, but you'r a villain:
He lov'd me well too; but you love my wife Sir,
After whom take you that? I will not ſay
Your Mother plaid falſe.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: No Sir, you were not beſt.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: But I will ſay, in ſpight of thee, my wife's honeſt.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And I, my Miſtriſs.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: You may, ile give you leave.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Leave, or leave not, there, ſhe defies you Sir;
Keep your adulterous ſheet to wind you in,
Or cover your forbidden parts at leaſt,
For fear you want one; many a leacher may
That ſins in Cambrick now.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And in Lawn too Maſter.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Nay read, and tremble Sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Now ſhall I do't Mr? I ſee a piece of an open ſeam in his Shirt, ſhall I run him in there, for my Sword has ne'r a point.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: No, let him foam a while.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: If your Sword be no better than mine, we ſhall not kill him by daylight, we had need have a Lanthorn.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Talk not of Lanthorns, he's a ſturdy Lecher,
He would make the horns fly about my ears.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I apprehend thee: admirable woman,
Which to love beſt I know not; thy wit, or beauty.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Now Sir, have you well viewd your baſtard there,
Got of your luſtfull brain? give you joy on't.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I thank you Sir, although you ſpeak in jeſt,
I muſt confeſs, I ſent your wife this letter,
And often courted her, tempted, and urg'd her.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Did you ſo Sir?
Then firſt before I kill thee, I for-warn thee my houſe▪

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And I before I kill thee, for-warn thee my office; dye to morrow next, thou never getſt Warrant of me more, for love, or money.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Remember but agen, from whence I came Sir,
And then I know you cannot think amiſs of me.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Pray hear him: it may grow to a peace:
sp.p: For Mr. though we have carried the buſineſs nobly, we are not altogether ſo valiant as we ſhould be.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Peace, thou ſayſt true in that: what is't you'ld ſay Sir?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Was not my Father, (quietneſs be with him)
And you ſworn Brothers?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Why Right: that's it urges me.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: And could you have a thought that I could wrong you,
As far as the deed goes?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: You took the courſe Sir.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: To make you happy, and you rightly weighd it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Troth ile put up at all adventures Mr.
It comes off very fair yet.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: You in years
Married a young Maid: what do's the world judge think you?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Birlady Mr. knaviſhly enough I warrant you,
I ſhould doe ſo my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Now to damp ſlander,
And all her envious and ſuſpitious brood,
I made this friendly tryall of her conſtancy,
Being Son to him you lov'd; that now confirm'd
I might advance my Sword againſt the world
In her moſt fair defence, which joys my ſpirit.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Oh Mr. let me weep while you embrace him.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Franciſco; is thy fathers ſoul in thee?
Lives he here ſtill? what, will he ſhew himſelf
In his male ſeed to me? give me thy hand,
Me thinks it feels now like thy fathers to me,
Prethee forgive me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And me to, prethee.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Come to my houſe, thy father never miſs'd it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Fetch now as many Warrants as you pleaſe Sir,
And welcome too.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: To ſee how ſoon mans goodneſs
May be abus'd.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: But now I know thy intent
Welcome to all that I have.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Sir, I take it:
A gift ſo given, hang him that would forſake it.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Martino, I applaud my fortune, and thy Counſell.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You never have ill fortune when you follow it.
Here was things carried now, in the true nature of a quiet Duello;
A great ſtrife ended, without the rough Souldier, or the—
And now you may take your journy.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Thou art my glee Martino.

div.head: Actus 2. Scaena 1.
div.stage: Enter VALERIA the Widow and a Servant.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: SErvellio.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: If that fellow come agen,
Anſwer him without me: ile not ſpeak with him.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: He in the Nutmeg-colourd band forſooth.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I, that ſpic'd-Coxcomb Sir: Never may I marry agen
If his right worſhipfull idolatrous face
Be not moſt fearfully painted, painted, ſo hope comfort me,
I might perceive it peel in many places,
And under's eye, lay a betraying fowlneſs,
As Maids ſweep duſt o'th' houſe, all to one corner,
It ſhewd me enough there, prodigious pride
That cannot but fall ſcornfully. I'm a woman,
Yet I praiſe heaven, I never had the ambition
To goe about to mend a better Workman,
She ever ſhames her ſelfi'th' end, that do's it.
He that likes me not now, as heaven made me,
I will never hazard hell to doe him a pleaſure;
Nor lye every night like a Woodcock in paſt
To pleaſe ſome gaudy Gooſe i'th' morning:
A wiſe man likes that beſt, that is it ſelf,
Not that which onely ſeems, though it look fairer;
Heaven ſend me one that loves me, and I'm happy,
Of whom ile make great tryall ere I have him,
Though I ſpeak all men fair, and promiſe ſweetly,
I learn that of my Suitors, 'tis their own,
Therefore injuſtice 'twere to keep it from 'em.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: And ſo as I ſaid ſweet Widow.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Doe you begin where you left Sir?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: I alwaies deſire when I come to a Window, to begin i'th' middle of a ſentence, for I preſume ſhe has a bad memory of a woman that cannot remember what goes before.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Stay, ſtay Sir, let me look upon you well,
Are not you painted too?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: How, painted, Widow?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Not painted Widow, I doe not uſe it truſt me Sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: That makes me love thee.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I mean painted Gentleman,
Or if you pleaſe to give him a greater ſtile Sir;
Blame me not Sir, its a dangerous age I tell you,
Poor ſimple dealing women had need look about 'em.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: But is there ſuch a fellow in the world, Widow,
As you are pleas'd to talk on?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Nay, here lately Sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Here? a Pox, I think I ſmell him, 'tis Vermillion ſure, ha: oil of Ben, doe but ſhow him me Widow, and let me never hope for comfort, if I doe not immediatly gueld him, and grind his face upon one o'th' ſtones.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Suffices y'have expreſt me your love and valour, and manly hate againſt that unmanly pride: but Sir, ile ſave you that labour, he never comes within my dore agen.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p:
Ile love your dore the better while I know't Widow; a pair of ſuch Brothers were fitter for Poſtes without dore indeed, to make a ſhew at a new-choſen Magiſtrates gate, than to be us'd in a Womans Chamber: No, ſweet Widow, having me, y'have
the truth of a man, all that you ſee of me, is full mine own, and what you ſee, or not ſee, ſhall be yours: I ever hated to be beholding to art, or to borrow any thing but money.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: True, and that you never uſe to pay agen.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: What matter i'ſt? if you be pleas'd to do't
For me, I hold it as good.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Oh, ſoft you Sir I pray.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Why 'yfaith you may and you will.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I know that Sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Troth, and I would have my will then if I were as you.
Ther's few women elſe but has.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: But ſince I cannot hav't in all Signior, I care not to have it in any thing.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Why you may hav't in all, and you will Widow.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Piſh, I would have one that loves me for my ſelf Sir,
Not for my wealth: and that I cannot have.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: What ſay you to him that do's the thing you wiſh for?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why here's my hand, ile marry none but him then.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Your hand, and faith.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My hand, and faith.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: 'Tis I then.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I ſhalbe glad on't truſt me: ſhrew my heart elſe.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: A match.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Give you joy, ſweet Widow.

sp.speaker: At.
sp.l: Joy to you both.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Nay, ther's no ſtarting now, I have you faſt Widow,
You'r witneſs Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Fra. Att.
sp.l: Wee'l be depos'd on't.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Am I betraid to this then? then I ſee
'Tis for my wealth; a womans wealth's her Traitour.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: 'Tis for love chiefly, I proteſt ſweet Widow,
I count wealth but a fiddle to make us merry.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Hence.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Why thou'rt mine.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I doe renonunce it utterly.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Have I not hand and faith?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sir, take your courſe.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: With all my heart; ten courſes and you will Widow.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sir, Sir, I'm not ſo gameſome as you think me,
Ile ſtand you out by law.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: By Law? O cruell mercileſs woman,
To talk of law, and know I have no money.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I will conſume my ſelf to the laſt ſtamp,
Before thou gett'ſt me.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: 'Life, ile be as wilfull then too: Ile rob all the Carriers in Chriſtendome, but ile have thee, and find my Lawyers money:
sp.l: I ſcorn to get thee under forma pauperis,
I have too proud a heart, and love thee better.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: As for you Gentlemen, ile take courſe againſt you;
You came into my houſe without my leave;
Your practices are cunning, and deceitfull;
I know you not, and I hope law will right me.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: It is ſufficient that your husband knows 'em,
'Tis not your buſineſs to know every man,
An honeſt wife contents her ſelf with one.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You know what you ſhall truſt to, pray depart Sir,
And take your rude confederates along with you,
Or I will ſend for thoſe ſhall force your abſence:
I'm glad I found your purpoſe out ſo ſoon.
How quickly may poor women be undone.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Loſe thee? by this hand ile fee fifteen Counſellours firſt, though I undoe a hundred poor men for 'em, and ile make 'em yaul one an other deaf, but ile have thee.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Me?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Thee.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I, fret thy heart out.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Were I he now
Il'd ſee thee ſtarve for man before I had thee.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Pray counſell him to that Sir, and ile pay you well.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Pay me? pay your next husband.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Doe not ſcorn't gallant: a worſe woman than I,
Has paid a better man than you.

div.l: 1 Why how now ſweet Widow?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Oh kind Gentlemen,
I am ſo abus'd here.

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.l: Abus'd?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What will you doe Sirs? put up your weapons.

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.p:
Nay, they'r not ſo eaſily drawn, that I muſt tell you
you, mine has not been out this three ears; mary in your cauſe Widow, 'twould not be long a drawing. Abus'd? by whom Widow?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Nay, by a begger.

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.p: A begger? Ile have him whipt then, and ſent to the houſe of Correction.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ricardo? Sir.

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.p: Ricardo? nay by'th' maſſe, he's a Gentleman begger, he'l be hang'd before he be whipt. Why you'l give me leave to clap him up I hope?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'Tis too good for him; that's the thing he would have,
He would be clapt up whether I would or no methinks;
Plac'd two of his companions privatly,
Unknown to me, on purpoſe to entrap me
In my kind anſwers, and at laſt ſtole from me,
That which I fear will put me to ſome trouble,
A kind of verball curteſie, which his witneſſes
And he forſooth call by the name of contract.

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: O politick villain,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But I am reſolv'd Gentlemen,
If the whole power of my eſtate can caſt him,
He never ſhall obtain me.

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.l: Hold you there Widow,
Well fare your heart for that y'faith.

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: Stay, ſtay, ſtay,
You broke no gold between you?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: We broke nothing Sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: Nor drunck to one an other?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Not a drop Sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: Y'ar ſure of this you ſpeak?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Moſt certain Sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: Be of good comfort wench, ile undertake then
At mine own charge to overthrow him for thee.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O doe but that Sir, and you bind me to you,
Here ſhall I try your goodneſs. I'm but a woman,
And alas, ignorant in Law buſineſſes,
Ile bear the charge moſt willingly.

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: Not a penny,
Thy love will reward me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And where love muſt be,
It is all but one purſe now I think on't.

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: All comes to one, ſweet Widow.

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.l: Are you ſo forward?

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: I know his mates Attilio and Franciſco,
Ile get out proceſs and and attach 'em all,
Wee'l begin firſt with them.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I like that, ſtrangely.

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: I have a daughter run away I thank her,
Ile be a ſcourge to all youth for her ſake:
Some of 'em has got her up.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Your daughter? what Sir? Martia.

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: I a ſhake wed her,
I would have married her to a wealthie Gentleman,
No older than my ſelf, ſhe was like to be ſhrewdly hurt Widow.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: It was too happy for her.

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: I'm of thy mind.
Farewell ſweet Widow, ile about this ſtrait,
Ile have 'em all three put into one Writ,
And ſo ſave charges.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: How I love your providence.

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.l: Is my Noſe board? Ile croſs ye both for this,
Although it coſt me as much o'th'other ſide,
I have enough, and I will have my humour.
I may get out of her, what may undoe her too;
Hark you ſweet Widow, you muſt now take heed,
You be of a ſure ground, hee'l overthrow your elſe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Marry fair hope forbid.

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.p: That will he: mary le' me ſee, le' me ſee: pray how far paſt it between you and Ricardo?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Farther Sir
Than I would now it had, but I hope well yet.

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.l: Pray let me hear't: I've a ſhrewd gheſſe o'th' Law.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Faith Sir, I raſhly gave my hand and faith
To marry none but him.

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.l: Indeed?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I, truſt me Sir.

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.l: I'm very glad on't, I'm an other witneſs,
And he ſhall have you now.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What ſaid you Sir.

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.l: He ſhall not want money in an honeſt cauſe Widow,
I know I have enough, and I will have my humour.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Are all the world betrayers.

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.l: Piſh, piſh, Widow.
Y'have borne me in hand this three months, and now fobd me
I've known the time when I could pleaſe a woman,
Ile not be laught at now; when I'm croſt, I'm a Tiger;
I have enough, and I will have my humour.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: This only ſhows your malice to me Sir,
The world knows you ha' ſmall reaſon to help him,
So much in your debt already.

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.l: Therefore I do't,
I have no way but that to help my ſelf;
Though I loſe you, I will not loſe all Widow;
He marrying you, as I will follow't for him,
Ile make you pay his debts, or lye without him.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I lookd for this from you.

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.l: I ha' not deceiv'd you then:
Fret, vex, and chafe, I'm obſtinate where I take.
Ile ſeek him out, and cheer him up, againſt her,
I ha' no charge at all, no child of mine own,
But two I got once of a ſcowring woman,
And they'r both well provided for, they'r i'th' Hoſpitall:
I have ten thouſand pound to bury me, and I will have my humour.

div.head: Scaena 2.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: A man muſt have a time to ſerve his pleaſure,
As well as his dear Friend, I'm forc'd to ſteal from 'em,
To get this night of ſport for mine own uſe▪
What ſays her amiable witty letter here?
'Twixt nine and ten, now 'tis 'twixt ſix and ſeaven,
As fit as can be; he that follows Lecherie,
Leaves all at ſix and ſeaven, and ſo doe I me thinks:
Sun ſets at eight, its 'bove an hour high yet,
Some fifteen mile have I before I reach her,
But I've an excellent horſe; and a good gallop,
Helps man as much as a provoking Banquet.

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: Here's one of 'em, begin with him firſt Officers.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.l: By vertue of this writ we attach your body Sir.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: My body? 'life, for what?

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: Hold him faſt Officers.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: The leaſt of us can do't, now his Sword's off Sir,
We have a trick of hanging upon Gentlemen,
We never loſe a man.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: O treacherous fortune,
Why what's the cauſe?

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: The Widow's buſineſs Sir,
I hope you know me?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: For a buſie Coxcomb,
This fifteen year, I take it.

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: Oh y'ar mad Sir,
Simple though you make me, I ſtand for the Widow.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: She's ſimply ſtood for then: what's this to me Sir,
Or ſhe, or you, or any of theſe fleſh-hooks?

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: Y'ar like to find good bayl before you leave us,
Or lye till the Suit's tride.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: O my loves miſery.

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.p: I'm put in truſt to follow't, and Ile do't with all ſeveritie;
sp.l: Build upon that Sir.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: How I would curſs my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Look, here's Franciſco,
Will you believe me, now you ſee his qualities?

sp.speaker: Attilio.
sp.l: 'Tis ſtrange to me.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I tell you 'tis his faſhion,
He never ſtole away in's life from me,
But ſtill I found him in ſuch ſcurvie Companie;
A pox on thee Franciſco wilt never leave thy old
Tricks, are theſe lowſy Companions for thee?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Piſh, piſh, piſh.

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: Here they be all three now: 'prehend 'em Officers.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: What's this?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I gave you warning enough to make away,
I'm in for the Widows buſineſs, ſo are you now.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: What, all three in a nooze? this is like a Widows buſineſs indeed.

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: Sh'as catchd you Gentlemen, as you catchd her,
The Widow means now, to begin with you Sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p:
I thank her heartily, ſh'as taught me wit: for had I been any but an aſs, I ſhould ha' begun with her indeed: by this light, the Widows a notable Houſe-wife, ſhe beſtirs her ſelf, I have a
greater mind to her now thau e'r I had: I cannot goe to priſon for one I love better I proteſt, that's one good comfort, And what are you I pray Sir, for a Coxcomb?

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: It ſeems you know me by your anger Sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I've a neer gheſs at you Sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: Gheſs what you pleaſe Sir,
I'm he ordaind to trounce you, and indeed
I am the man muſt carry her.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I, to me.
But Ile ſwear ſhe's a beaſt, and ſhe carry thee.

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: Come, wher's your Bail Sir, quickly, or away.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Sir, I'm held wrongfully, my Bayls taken already.

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: Where i'ſt Sir, where?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Here they be both: pox on you, they were taken before I'd need of 'em, and you be honeſt Officers let's Bail one another, for by this hand, I doe not know who will elſe:—'odds' light is he come too? I'm in for midnight then, I ſhall never find the way out agen: my debts, my debts:

div.l: I'm like to dye i'th' hole now.

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: We have him faſt old Signior, and his Conſorts,
Now you may lay action on action on him.

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.l: That may I Sir, y'faith.

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: And I'ld not ſpare him Sir.

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.l: Know you me Officers?

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.l: Your bounteous worſhip Sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I know the raſcall ſo well, I dare not look upon him.

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.l: Upon my worth deliver me that Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Which Gentleman?

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.l: Not you Sir, y'ar too haſtie;
No, nor you neither Sir: pray ſtay your time.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Ther's all but I now, and I dare not think he means me.

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.l: Deliver me Ricardo.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: O ſure he lyes.
Or elſe I doe not hear well.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.l: Signior Ricardo.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Well, what's the matter? you may goe, who let's you?

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.l: It is his worſhips pleaſure Sir to Bayl you.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Bayl me?

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.l: I will, I Sir, look in my face man,
Thou'ſt a good cauſe, thoul't pay me when thour't able?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I, every penny, as I am a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.l: No matter if thou do'ſt not, then, Ile make thee,
And that's as good at all times.

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: But I pray Sir,
You goe againſt the Hair there.

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.l: Againſt the Widow you mean Sir,
Why 'tis my purpoſe truly, and againſt you too,
I ſaw your politick Combination,
I was thruſt out between you: here ſtands one
Shall doe as much for you, and he ſtands righteſt,
His cauſe is ſtrong and fair, nor ſhall he want
Money, or means, or friends, but he ſhall have her,
I've enough, and I will have my humour.

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: Hang thee; I have a purſs as good as thine.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I think they'r much alike, they'r rich knaves both.
'Heart, and I take your rayling at my Patron Sir,
Ile cramp your joynts.

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.l: Let him alone ſweet honey,
I thank thee for thy love though.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: This is wonderfull.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Oh Ricardo,
'Tis ſeaven, ſtruck in my pocket: I loſe time now.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: What ſayſt Franciſco?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I ha' mighty buſineſs,
That I ne'r thought on: get me Baild, I'm ſpoild elſe.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Why you know, 'tis ſuch a ſtrange miraculous curteſie,
I dare not be too forward, to aske more of him,
For fear he repent this, and turn me in agen.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Doe ſomewhat and you love me.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Ile make tryall 'faith
May't pleaſe you Sir:—'life if I ſhould ſpoil all now?

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.l: What ſayſt Ricardo?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Only a thing by'th'way Sir,
Uſe your own pleaſure.

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.l: That I like well from thee.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: 'Twere good, and thoſe two Gentlemen were Bayld too,
They'r both my witneſſes.

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.l: They'r well, they'r well:
And they were Bayld, we know not where to find 'em,
Let 'em goe to priſon, they'l be forth-comming the better,
I have enough, and I will have my humour.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I knew there was no more good to be done upon him,
'Tis well I've this, heav'n knows I never lookt for't.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: What plaguy luck had I to be enſnar'd thus?

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.l: O, patience.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Pox O your comfortable ignorance.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Martino, we ride ſlow.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: But we ride ſure Sir,
Your haſtie riders often come ſhort home Mr.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: 'Bleſs this fair companie.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Here he's agen too,
I am both ſham'd, and croſs'd.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: See'ſt thou who's yonder, Martino?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: We ride ſlow, ile beſworn now Mr.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: How now Franciſco, art thou got before me?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Yes, thank my fortune, I am got before you.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: What no? in hold?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I, o' my troth poor Gentleman,
Your worſhip Sir, may doe a good deed to Bayl him.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Why doe not you do't then?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: La you Sir now, my Mr. h'as that honeſtie
He's loth to take a good deed from you Sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Ile tell you why I cannot, elſe I would Sir.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Luck I beſeech thee,
If he ſhould be wrought to Bail me now, to goe to
His wife, 'twere happineſs beyond expreſſion.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: A matter but of controverſie.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: That's all, truſt me Sir.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Franciſco ſhall ne'r lye for't; he's my friend,
And I will Bayl him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: He's your ſecret friend Mr.
Think upon that.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Give him his liberty Officers,
Upon my perill, he ſhalbe forth comming.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: How I am bound to you?

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: Know you whom you croſs Sir?
'Tis at your Siſters ſute, be well advis'd Sir,

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: How, at my Siſters ſute? take him agen then.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Why Sir, doe you refuſe me?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Ile not hear thee.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: This is unkindly done ſir.

sp.speaker: 1 ſuter.
sp.l: 'Tis wiſely done ſir.

sp.speaker: 2 ſuter.
sp.l: Well ſhot, foul malice.

sp.speaker: 1 ſuter.
sp.l: Flattery ſtinks worſe ſir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: You'l never leave till I make you ſtink as bad ſir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Oh Martino, have I this for my late kindneſs?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Alas poor Gentleman, doſt complain to me?
Thou ſhalt not fare the worſe for't: Hark you Maſter,
Your ſiſters ſute ſaid you?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: I ſir, my wifes ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And ſhall that dant you Maſter? think agen,
Why wer't your mothers ſute; your mothers ſute,
Mark what I ſay, the deareſt ſute of all ſutes,
You'r bound in conſcience ſir to bayl this Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Yea, am I ſo, how proov'ſt thou that Martino?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Have you forgot ſo ſoon, what he did lately?
Has he not tri'd your wife to your hand maſter?
To cut the throat of ſlander and ſuſpition;
And can you do too much for ſuch a man?
Shall it be ſaid, I ſerve an ingratfull maſter?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Never Martino; I will bayl him now,
And 'twere at my wives ſute.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: 'Tis like to be ſo.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And I his friend, to follow your example Mr.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Precious Martino.

sp.speaker: 1 ſuter.
sp.l: Y'ave done wondrous well ſir.
Your ſiſter ſhall give you thanks.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: This makes him mad ſir.

sp.speaker: 2 ſuter.
sp.l: Wee'l follow't now toth' proof.

sp.speaker: 1 ſuter.
sp.l: Follow your humour out,
The widdow ſhall find friends.

sp.speaker: 2 ſuter.
sp.l: And ſo ſhall he ſir,
Mony and means.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Hear you me that old huddle.

sp.speaker: 2 ſuter.
sp.l: Mind him not, follow me and ile ſupply thee,
Thou ſhalt give all thy Lawyers double fees,
I've burryed mony enough to burry me,
And I will have my humour.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Fare thee well once again my dear Franciſco,
I prethee uſe my houſe.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: It is my purpoſe ſir.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Nay you muſt do't then; though I am old, I'm free.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And when you want a warrant, come to me.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: That will be ſhortly now, within this few hours.
This fell out ſtrangely happy. Now to horſe,
I ſhall be nighted; but an hour or two
Never breaks ſquare in love; he comes in time
That comes at all; abſence is all loves crime.

div.head: Actus 3. Scaena 1.
div.stage: Enter OCCULTO, SILVIO, and two or three other Thieves.

sp.speaker: Occulto.
sp.l: COme, come, let's watch th'event on yonder hill,
If he need help, we can releive him ſudainly.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I, and with ſafetie too, the hill being watcht Sir.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: Have you the Blew cotes and the Beards?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: They'r here Sir.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: Come, come away then, a fine Cock ſhoot evening.

div.stage: Enter Latrocinio the chief Thief, and Anſoldo.

sp.speaker: La. ſings.
sp.l: Kuck before, and Kuck behind, &c.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: Troth y'ar the merrieſt, and delightfulſt company Sir,
That ever Traveller was bleſt withall,
I praiſe my fortune that I overtook you Sir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Piſh, I've a hundred of 'em.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: And beleeve me Sir,
I'm infinitely taken with ſuch things.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I ſee ther's muſick in you, you kept time me thought
Prety and handſomly with your little hand there.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: It only ſhews deſire, but troth, no skill Sir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Well, while our horſes walk down yonder hill Sir,
Ile have an other for you.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: It rids way pleaſantly.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Le' me ſee now: one confounds an other ſir,
Y'have heard this certainly: Come my daintie Doxes.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: Oh, that's all the Country over ſir,
Ther's ſcarce a Gentlewoman, but has that prickt.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Well, here comes one I'm ſure you never heard then.
I keep my Horſe, I keep my Whore,
I take no Rents, yet am not poor;
I traverſe all the Land about,
And yet was born to never a foot:
With Partridge plump, with Woodcock fine
I doe at midnight often dine;
And if my Whore be not in caſe,
My Hoſteſſe daughter h'as her place;
The Maids ſit up, and watch their turns,
If I ſtay long the Tapſter mourns;
The Cook-maid has no mind to ſin,
Though tempted by the Chamber lin;
But when I knock, oh how they buſtle,
The Oſtler yawns, the Geldings juſtle.
If Maid but ſleep, oh how they curſe hir!
And all this comes of, Deliver your purſe ſir.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: How Sir?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Few words: quickly come, deliver your purſe ſir.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: Y'ar not that kind of Gentleman, I hope ſir,
To ſing me out of my money?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: 'Tis moſt ſit
Art ſhould be rewarded: you muſt pay your Muſick ſir
Where ere you come.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: But not at your own carving.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Nor am I cōmon in't: Come, come your purſe ſir.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: Say it ſhould prove the undoing of a Gentleman?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Why ſir, doe you looke for more conſcience in us, than
In Uſurers? young gentleman, y'have ſmall reaſon for that y'faith.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: There 'tis, and all I have; and ſo truth comfort me,
All I know where to have.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Sir, that's not written
In my belief yet; ſearch, 'tis a fine evening,
Your horſe can take no harm: I muſt have more ſir.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: May my hopes periſh, if you have not all ſir,
And more I know than your compaſſionate charitie
Would keep from me, if you but felt my wants.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: Search, and that ſpeedily: if I take you in hand,
You'l find me rough, me thinks men ſhould be rul'd,
When they'r ſo kindly ſpoke too, fy upon't.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: Good fortune, and my wit aſſiſt me then,
A thing I took in haſte, and never thought on't:
Look ſir, I've ſearch'd, here's all that I can find,
And you'r ſo covetous, you will have all you ſay,
And I'm content you ſhall, being kindly ſpoke too.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: A pox o' that young devill of a handfull long.
That 'as fraid many a tall thief from a rich purchaſe.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: This, and my money ſir, keeps company;
Where one goes, th'other muſt; aſſure your ſoul
They vow'd never to part.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Hold, I beſeech you ſir.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: You rob a priſoners box, and you rob me, ſir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: There 'tis agen.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: I knew 't would never proſper with you;
Fy, rob a younger Brother, oh take heed ſir,
'Tis againſt nature that, perhaps your Father
Was one ſir, or your Uncle, it ſhould ſeem ſo
By the ſmall means was left you, and leſſe manners.
Goe, keep you ſtill before me, and do you hear me;
To paſſe away the time to the next Town,
I charge you ſir, ſing all your Songs for nothing—

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: Oh horrible puniſhment.—A Song:

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Honeſt Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: How now, what art thou?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Stand you in need of help?
I made all haſte I could, my Maſter charg'd me.
A Knight of worſhip; he ſaw you firſt aſſaulted.
From top of yonder hill.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: Thanks honeſt friend.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I taſte this trick already.—

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Look, hee's gone ſir,
Shall he be ſtop'd; what is he?

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: Let him goe ſir;
He can rejoyce in nothing, that's the comfort.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: You have your purſe ſtill then?

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: I, thanks fair fortune,
And this grym handfull.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: We were all ſo fraid o'you,
How my good Lady cri'd Ohelp the gentleman,
'Tis a good woman that: but you'r too mild ſir,
You ſhould ha' markt him for a villain 'faith
Before h'ad gone, having ſo ſound a means too.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: Why there's the jeſt man; he had once my purſe.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Oh▪ villain, would you let him ſcape unmaſacred?

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: Nay, hear me ſir, I made him yield it ſtreight agen,
And ſo hope bleſſe me, with an uncharg'd Piſtoll.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: 'Troth I ſhould laugh at that.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: It was diſcharg'd Sir,
Before I medled with't.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: I'me glad to hear't.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: Why how now, What's your will?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Hoh, Latrocinio, Occulto, Silvio.—

div.stage: [Enter Latrocinio and the reſt, Occulto, Silvio, Fiducio.]

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What are you caught ſir?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: The Piſtoll cannot ſpeak.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: He was too young,
I ever thought he could not; yet I fear'd him.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: Y'have found out waies too mercileſs to betray
Under the veil of friendſhip, and of charitie.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Away ſirs, bear him in to th' next Cops, and ſtrip him.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Brandino's Copps, the Juſtice?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Beſt of all ſit, a man of law?
A Spider lies unſuſpected in the corner of a buckeram bag, man.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: What ſeek you ſirs? take all and uſe no crueltie,

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: You ſhall have Songs enough.
How round the world goes, and every thing that's in it,
The Tydes of gold and ſilver, ebb and flow in a minute:
From the Uſurer to his Sons, there a current ſwiftly runs,
From the Sons to Queans in chief, from the gallant to the Thief,
From the Thief unto his Hoſt, from the Hoſt to Husband-men;
From the Country to the Court, and ſo it comes to us agen.
How round the world goes, and every thing that's in it,
The Tides of gold and ſilver, ebb and flow in a minute.
sp.stage: Enter PHILIPP A and VIOLETTA above at the Window.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What time of night is't?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Time of night doe you call't?
Its ſo late, 'tis almoſt early Miſtriſs.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Fy on him, ther's no looking for him then;
Why ſure this Gentleman apprehends me not.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: 'Tis happy then y'arrid of ſuch a fool Miſtriſs.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nay ſure Wench, if he find me not out in this
Which were a beaten path to any wiſeman,
Ile never truſt him with my reputation;
Therefore I made this tryall of his wit,
If he cannot conceive what's good for himſelf,
He will worſe underſtand what's good for me.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: But ſuppoſe Mrs. as it may be likely,
He never ſaw your letter?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How thou plyeſt me,
With ſuppoſitions? why I tell thee wench,
Tis equally as impoſſible for my husband
To keep it from him, as to be young agen,
Or as his firſt wife knew him, which he brags on
For bearing children by him.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Ther's no remedy then,
I muſt conclude Franciſco is an Aſs.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I would my letter, wench, were here agen,
I'ld know him wiſer ere I ſent him one;
And travail ſome five year firſt.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: So h'ad need methinks,
To underſtand the words, methinks the words
Themſelves ſhould make him do't, had he but the perſeverance
Of a Cock ſparrow, that will come at philip,
And can nor write, nor read poor fool, this Coxcomb
He can doe both, and your names but Philippa,
And yet to ſee, if he can come when's calld,

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: He never ſhall be calld agen for me ſirha.
Well, as hard as the world goes, wee'l have a Song we nch,
Wee'l not ſit up for nothing.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: That's poor comfort though.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Better then any's brought, for ought I ſee yet? So ſet to your Lute.
sp.l: 1 If in this queſtion I propound to thee
Be any, any choice,
Let me have thy voice.
2 You ſhall moſt free.
I Which hadſt thou rather be
If thou might chooſe thy life,
A Fools, a fools Miſtriſs,
Or an old mans wife?
2 The choice is hard, I know not which is beſt,
One ill y'ar bound too, and I think that's leaſt.
1 But being not bound, my deareſt ſweet,
I could ſhake off the other.
2 Then as you loſe your ſport by one,
You loſe your name by t'other.
1 You counſell well, but love refuſes,
What good counſell often chooſes.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: I ha' got my ſelf unbound yet: mercileſs villains,
I never felt ſuch hardneſs ſince life dwelt in me;
'Tis for my ſins: That light in yonder Window
That was my only comfort in the woods,
Which oft the trembling of a leaf would loſe me,
Has brought me thus far, yet I cannot hope
For ſuccour in this plight, the world's ſo pittileſs,
And every one will fear or doubt me now:
To knock will be to bold, ile to the gate,
And liſten if I can hear any ſtirring.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Was ever man ſo croſs'd? no 'tis but ſweat ſure,
Or the dew dropping from the leaves above me,
I thought'thad bled agen: theſe wenching buſineſſes
Are ſtrange unlucky things, and fatall fooleries,
No mar'l ſo many gallants die ere thirtie,
'Tis able to vex out a mans heart in five year,
The croſſes that belong to't: firſt arreſted,
That ſet me back two mangey hours at leaſt,
Yet that's a thing my heat could have forgiv'n,
Becauſe arreſting, in what kind ſoever,
Is a moſt Gentleman-like affliction:
But here, within a mile o'th' town forſooth,
And two mile off this place, when a mans oath
Might ha'been taken for his own ſecuritie,
And his thoughts brisk, and ſet upon the buſineſs,
To light upon a roguy flight of Thieves,
Pox on'em, here's the length of one of their whiſtles,
But one of my dear Raſcals, I purſued ſo,
The Gaol has him, and he ſhall bring ou'ts fellows:
Had ever young mans love ſuch crooked fortune?
I'm glad I'm ſo neer yet; the Surgeon bad me too
Have a great care; I ſhall never think of that now.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: One of the Theeves come back agen? Ile ſtand cloſe;
He dares not wrong me now, ſo neer the houſe,
And call in vain 'tis, till I ſee him offer't.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: 'Life, what ſhould that be? a prodigious thing
Stands juſt as I ſhould enter, in that ſhape too,
Which alwaies appears terrible.
What ere it be, it is made ſtrong againſt me
By my ill purpoſe. For'tis mans own ſin
That puts on armor upon all his evils,
And gives them ſtrength to ſtrike him: were it leſs
Then what it is, my guilt would make it ſerve;
A wicked mans own ſhadow has diſtracted him:
Were this a buſineſs now to ſave an honour,
As 'tis to ſpoil one, I would paſs this then
Stuck all hels horrors i'thee: now I dare not.
Why may't not be the ſpirit of my Father
That lov'd this man ſo well, whom I make haſte
Now to abuſe? And I have been croſs'd about it
Moſt fearfully hitherto, if I well think on't;
Scap'd death but lately too, nay moſt miraculouſly;
And what do's fond man venture all theſe ills for,
That may ſo ſweetly reſt in honeſt peace?
For that which being obtaind, is as he was
To his own ſence but remov'd neerer ſtill
To death eternall: what delight has man
Now at this preſent, for his pleaſant ſin
Of yeſterdaies committing? 'las, 'tis vaniſh'd,
And nothing but the ſting remains within him.
The kind man baild me too; I will not do't now
And 'twere but only that: how bleſt were man,
Might he but have his end appear ſtill to him,
That he might read his actions i'th' event?
'T would make him write true, though he never meant.
Whoſe Check ſo ere thou art, Fathers, or Friends,
Or Enemies, I thank thee, peace require thee;
Light, and the lighter Miſtris both farewell.
He keeps his promiſe beſt that breaks with hell.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: He's gone to call the reſt, and makes all ſpeed,
Ile knock what ere befalls, to pleaſe my fears,
For no compaſſion can be leſſe than theirs.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: He's come, he's come; oh are you come at laſt ſir?
Make little noiſe, away, he'll knock agen els.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: I ſhould have bin at I ſtria by day-break too,
Neer to Valerias houſe the wealthy Widowes,
There waites one purpoſely to doe me good.
What will become of me?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Oh, y'ar a ſweet Gallant, this your hour?
Give me your hand; come, come ſir, follow me,
Ile bring you to light preſently: ſoftly, ſoftly ſir. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I ſhould ha' given him up to all my thoughts
The dulleſt young man, if he had not found it;
So ſhort of apprehenſion, and ſo worthleſs,
He were not fit for womans fellowſhip;
I've been at coſt too for a Banket for him;
Why't would ha' kill'd my heart, and moſte ſpecially
To think that man ſhould ha'no more conceit;
I ſhould ha' thought the worſe on's wit for ever,
And blam'd mine own for too much forwardneſs.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Oh Miſtris, Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How now, what's the news?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Oh, I was out of my wits for a minute and a half.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Hah?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: They are ſcarce ſetled yet Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Doe you ask that ſeriouſly?
Did you not hear me ſqueak?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How? ſure thou'rt out of thy wits indeed.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Oh, I'm well now,
To what I was Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why where's the gentleman?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: The gentleman's forth-comming, and a lovely one,
But not Franciſco.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What ſai'ſt, not Franciſco?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Piſh, hee's a coxcomb, think not on him Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What's all this?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I'ave often heard you ſay, ye'ad rather have
A wiſe man in his ſhirt than a Fool featherd,
And now fortune has ſent you one, a ſweet young gentleman,
Rob'd ev'n to nothing but what firſt he brought with him,
The ſlaves had ſtript him to th' very ſhirt Miſtris,
I think it was a ſhirt, I know not well,
For Gallants wear both now adayes.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: This is ſtrange.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: But for a face, a hand, and as much skin
As I durſt look upon, hee's a moſt ſweet one;
Franciſco is a child of Egypt to him:
I could not but in pitty to th' poor gentleman,
Fetch him down one of my old Maſters Suits.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'Twas charitably done,

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: You'ld ſay Miſtris, if you had ſeen him as I did.
Sweet youth, Ile be ſworn Miſtris hee's the lovelieſt
Proper'ſt young gentleman, and ſo you'l ſay your ſelf,
If my Maſters clothes do not ſpoil him, that's all the fear now,
I would't had been your luck to have ſeen him
Without'em, but for ſcarring on you.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Go, pre'thee fetch him in whom thou cōmend'ſt ſo,

div.l: Since fortune ſends him ſurely wee'll make much on him;
And better he deſerves our love, and welcome,
Than the reſpectleſs fellow 'twas prepar'd for;
Yet if he pleaſe mine eſe never ſo happily,
I will have tryall of his wit, and faith,
Before I make him partner with my honour,
'Twas juſt Franciſco's caſe, and he deceiv'd me;
Ile take more heed o'th' next ſor't; perhaps now
To furniſh his diſtreſs, he will appear
Full of fair promiſing Courtſhip; but Ile prove him then
For a next meeting, when he needs me not,
And ſee what he performs then when the ſtorm
Of his ſo rude misfortunes is blown over,
And he himſelf agen: A diſtreſt mans flatteries
Are like vowes made in drink, or bonds in priſon,
There's poor aſſurance in 'em: when hee's from me,
And in's own powr, then I ſhall ſee his love.
'Maſſe here he comes.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: Never was ſtar-croſs'd gentleman
More happy in a curteous virgins love,
Than I in yours.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I'm ſorry they'r no better for you,
I wiſh'd 'em hanſomer, and more in faſhion,
But truly Sir, our houſe affords it not:
There is a Suit of our Clerks, hangs i'th' garret,
But that's far worſe than this, if I may judge
With modeſtie of mens matters.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: I deſerve not
This, dear, and kind gentlewoman, is yond' your Miſtris?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why truſt me, here's my Husband young agen,
It is no ſin to welcome you, Sweet gentleman.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: I am ſo much indebted, curteous Lady,
To the unmatched charitie of your houſe,
My thanks are ſuch poor things they would but ſhame me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Beſhrew thy heart for bringing o'him: I fear me
I have found wit enough already in him,
If I could truly but reſolve my ſelf
My husband was thus handſome at nineteen,
'Troth I ſhould think the better of him at fourſcore now.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Nay Miſtris, what would he be, were he in faſhion,
A hempen curſe on thoſe that put him out on't,
That now appears ſo handſome, and ſo comely in clothes
Able to make a man an unbeleever,
And good for nothing but for ſhift, or ſo
If a man chance to fall i'th' ditch with better?
This is the beſt, that ever I mark'd in 'em,
A man may make him ready in ſuch clothes
Without a candle.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I for ſhame of himſelf Wench.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: My Maſter do's it oft in winter mornings,
And never ſees himſelf till he be ready.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: No, nor then neither, as he ſhould do Wench.
I am ſorry gentle Sir, we cannot ſhew you
A curteſie, in all points anſwerable
To your undoubted worth: your name I crave ſir.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: Anſaldo, Lady.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'Tis a noble name Sir.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: The moſt unfortunate now.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: So doe I think truly
As long as that Suites on.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: The moſt unfitting,
And unprovideſt ſir of all our curteſies,
I doe preſume is that y'have paſt already,
Your pardon but for that, and wee'r encourag'd.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: My faithfull ſervice, Lady.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Pleaſe you Sir
To taſte the next a poor ſlight Bancket, for ſure I think you were▪
Unluckily prevented of your ſupper ſir.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: My fortune makes me more than amends Lady,
In your ſweet kindneſſe, which ſo nobly ſhown to me,
It makes me bold to ſpeak my occaſions to you:
I am this morning, that with cleerneſs now
So chearfully haſtens me, to meet a Friend
Upon my ſtates eſtabliſhing, and the place
Ten mile from hence: oh, I am forc'd unwillingly
To crave your leave for't, which done I return
In ſervice plentifull.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Is't ſo important?

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: If I ſhould fail, as much as my undoing.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I think too well of you, to undo you ſir,
Upon this ſmall acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: My great happineſs.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: But when ſhould I be ſure of you here agen ſir?

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: As faſt as ſpeed can poſſibly return me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: You will not fail?

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: May never wiſh goe well with me then.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: There's to bear charges ſir.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: Curteſie dwells in you.
I brought my horſe up with me from the woods,
That's all the good they left me, 'gainſt their wils too,
May your kind breaſt never want comfort Lady,
But ſtill ſupply'd, as liberally as you give.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Farewell ſir, and be faithfull.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: Time ſhall prove me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: In my opinion now, this young mans likelieſt
To keep his word, he's modeſt, wiſe, and curteous;
He has the language of an honeſt ſoul in him:
A womans reputation may lye ſafe there,
I'm much deceiv'd elſe, h'as a faithfull eye
If it be well obſerv'd.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Good ſpeed be with thee ſir;
He puts him to't y'faith.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Violetta.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Miſtriſs.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Alas, what have we done wench?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: What's the matter Miſtriſs?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Run, run, call him agen; he muſt ſtay tell him;
Though it be upon's undoing, wee'r undone elſe,
Your Maſters cloaths, their known the Country over.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Now by this light that's true, and well remembred,
But ther's no calling of him, he's out of ſight now.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Oh what will people think?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: What can they think Miſtriſs?
The Gentleman has the worſt on't: were I he now
I'ld make this ten mile, forty mile about
Before Il'd ride through any market town with 'em.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Will he be carefull think'ſt?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: My life for yours Miſtriſs.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I ſhall long mightily to ſee him agen.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: And ſo ſhall I, I ſhall nev'r laugh till then.

div.head: Actus 4. Scaena 1.
div.stage: Enter RICARDO and 2 Suter at one dore, and VALERIA, and 1 Suter at another dore.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: IT goes well hitherto, my ſweet Protector.

sp.speaker: 2 Suter.
sp.l: I, and ſhall ſtill to th' end, to th' end my honey,
Wherefore have I enough, but to hav't goe well ſir?

sp.speaker: 1 Suter.
sp.l: My whole State on't; thou overthrowſt him Widow.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I hope well ſtill ſir.

sp.speaker: 1 Suter.
sp.l: Hope? be certain Wench:
I make no queſtion now, but thou art mine,
As ſure as if I had thee in thy night-geer.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: By'r Lady, that I doubt Sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Suter.
sp.l: Oh 'tis cleer wench
By one thing that I markt.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What's that good ſweet ſir?

sp.speaker: 1 Suter.
sp.l: A thing that never faild me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Good ſir, what?

sp.speaker: 1 Suter.
sp.l: I heard our Counſellour ſpeak a word of comfort
Invita voluntate, hah, that's he wench,
The word of words, the precious chiefy's faith.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Invita voluntate, what's the meaning ſir?

sp.speaker: 1 Suter.
sp.l: Nay there I leave you, but aſſure you thus much,
I never heard him ſpeak that word i' my life,
But the cauſe went on's ſide, that I market ever.

sp.speaker: 2 Suter.
sp.l: Doe, doe, and ſpare not: thou wouldſt talk with her.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Yes, with your leave, and liking.

sp.speaker: 2 Suter.
sp.l: Doe, my adoption,
My choſen child, and thou holdſt ſo obedient
Sure thou wilt live, and cozen all my kindred.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: A Childs part in your love, that's my ambition ſir.

sp.speaker: 2 Suter.
sp.l: Goe, and deſerve it then: pleaſe me well now;
I love wrangling a life Boy; ther's my delight,
I have no other venery but vexation,
That's all my honey now: ſmartly now to her,
I've enough and I will have my humour.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: This need not ha'been Widow.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You ſay right ſir.
No, nor your treacherie, your cloſe conſpiracie
Againſt me for my wealth, need not ha' been neither.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I had your fairly, I ſcorn treacherie
To your woman that I never ment to marry,
Much more to you whom I reſerv'd for wife.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: How, wiſe?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I, Wife, Wife, Widow, be not aſhamd on't,
It's the beſt calling ever woman came to,
And all your grace indeed, brag as you liſt.

sp.speaker: 2 Suter.
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I grant you ſir, But not to be your wife.

sp.speaker: 1 Suter.
sp.l: Oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Not mine? I think 'tis the beſt bargain
That ere thou mad'ſt i'thy life, or ever ſhall agen,
When my heads laid: but that's not yet this threeſcore year,
Let's talk of neerer matters.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Y'ar as neer ſir
As ere y'ar like to be, if Law can right me.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Now before conſcience, y'ar a wilfull houſewife.

sp.speaker: Val.
