sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I, and I fear you ſpend my goods laviſhly.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Your goods?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I ſhall miſs much I doubt me,
When I come to look over the Inventorie.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ile give you my word you ſhall ſir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Look too't Widow,
A night may come will call you to accompt for't.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Oh if you had me now ſir in this heat
I doe but think how youl'd be reveng'd on me.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I, may I periſh elſe; if I would not get
Three Children at a birth, and I could o'thee.

sp.speaker: 1 Suter.
sp.l: Take off your yongſter there.

sp.speaker: 2 Suter.
sp.l: Take off your Widow firſt,
He ſhall have the laſt word, I pay for't dearly;
To her agen ſweet Boy, that ſides the weaker.
I have enough, and I will have my humor.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O Brother ſee I'm up to th' ears in law here;
Look, Copy upon Copie.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: 'Twere grief enough if a man did but hear on't
But I'm in pain to ſee't.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What ſore eys ſtill Brother?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Worſe, and worſe Siſter; the old womans water
Do's me no good.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why, 't'as helpt many ſir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: It helps not me I'm ſure—Marti, Oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What ayls Martino too?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Oh, oh, the tooth-ach, the tooth-ach.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Ah poor worm, this he endures for me now.
There beats not a more mutuall pulſe of paſſion,
In a kind husband when his wife breeds child,
Than in Martino; I ha' mark't it ever,
He breeds all my pains in's teeth ſtill: and to quit me,
It is his eye-tooth too.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I, I, I, I.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Where did I hear late of a skilfull fellow,
Good for all kind of Malladies? true, true ſir,
His flag hangs out in town here, i'th' Croſs Inn,
With admirable cures of all conditions,
It ſhews him a great travelling, and learnd Emperick.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Wee'll both to him Martino.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Hark you Brother,
Perhaps you may prevail, as one indifferent.

sp.speaker: 1 Suter.
sp.l: I, about that ſweet Widow.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: True; ſpeak low ſir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Well, what's the buſineſs, ſay, ſay.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Mary this Brother.
Call the young man aſide, from the old Woolf there,
And whiſper in his ear a thouſand dollars
If he will vaniſh, and let fall the Sute,
And never put's to no more coſt and trouble.

sp.speaker: 1 Suter.
sp.l: Say me thoſe words good ſir, Ile make 'em worth
A chain of gold to you, at your Siſters wedding.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I ſhall doe much for that.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Welcome ſweet heart,
Thou com'ſt moſt happily, I'm bold to ſend for thee
To make a purpoſe good.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I take delight forſooth
In any ſuch employment.

sp.speaker: 1 Suter.
sp.l: 'Good wench truſt me

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: How Sir, let fall the Sute? 'life Ile goe naked firſt.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: A thouſand Dollars ſir, think upon them.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Why they'r but a thouſand Dollars, when they'r thought on.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: A good round ſumme.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: A good round Widow's better,
There's meat and money too. I have been bought
Out of my lands, and yielded, but (ſir) ſcorn
To be bought out of my affection.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Why here's ev'n juſt my Univerſitie ſpirit,
I priz'd a piece of red Deer, above gold then.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: My Patron would be mad, and he ſhould hear on't.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I pray what's good Sir, for a wicked tooth?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Hang'd, drawn, and quartring; is't a hollow one?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I 'tis a hollow one.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Then take the powder
Of a burnt Warrant, mixt with oil of Felon.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why ſure you mock me.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: 'Troth I think I doe ſir.

sp.speaker: 2. Suter.
sp.l: Come hither honey; What's the news in whiſpers?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: He will not be bought out.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No? that's ſtrange Brother.
Pray take a little pains about this project then,
And try what that effects.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I like this better;
Look you ſweet Gentles, ſee what I produce here
For amities ſake, and peace, to end all controverſie;
This Gentlewoman my charge left by her friends,
Whom for hir perſon, and hir portion,
I could beſtow moſt richly, but in pittie
To her affection, which lyes bent at you ſir,
I am content to yield to her deſire.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: At me?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: But for this jar, 't had ne'r been offerd.
I bring you fleſh, and money, a rich heir,
And a Maid too, and that's a thing worth thanks, ſir:
Nay, one that has rid fifteen mile this morning
For your love onely.

sp.speaker: 2. Suter.
sp.l: Honey, hearken after her;
Being rich, I can have all my money there:
Eaſe my purſe well, aud never wage law further.
I have enough, yet I will have my humour.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Doe you love me forſooth?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Oh infinitely.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I doe not ask thee, that I meant to have thee,
But only to know what came in thy head to love me.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: My time was come ſir, that's all I can ſay.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: 'Las poor ſoul, where didſt thou love me firſt prethee?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: In happy hour be't ſpoke, out at a window ſir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: A window? prithee clap it too, and call it in agen:
What was I doing then ſhould make thee love me?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Twiriling your band-ſtring, which me thought became you ſo generouſly well.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: 'Twas a good quality to chooſe a husband for: That love was likely to be ty'd in Matrimonie, that begun in a bandſtring: yet I ha' known aſmuch come to paſſe ere now upon a taſſell. Fare you well Siſter; I may be cozend in a Maid, I cannot in a Widow.

sp.speaker: 2. Suter.
sp.l: Art thou come home agen; ſtickſt thou there ſtill?
I will defend thee ſtill then.

sp.speaker: 1. Suter.
sp.l: Sir you malice
Will have enough on't.

sp.speaker: 2. Suter.
sp.l: I will have my humour.

sp.speaker: 1. Sut.
sp.l: Beggery will prove the ſpunge.

sp.speaker: 2. Sut.
sp.l: Spunge i' thy gaſcoyns,
Thy gally-gaſcoyns there.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Hah brave Protector.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I thought 'twould come to open Wars agen,
Let 'em agree as they will; two teſtie Fopps,
Ile have a care of mine eyes.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I, of my chops.

div.head: Scaena 2.
div.stage: Enter Latrocinio and Occulto, (a Banner of Cures and Diſeaſes hung out.)

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Away, out with the Banner, ſend's good luck to day.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: I warrant you; your name's ſpread Sir, for an Emperick.
Theres an old Maſon troubled with the Stone,
Has ſent to you this morning for your counſell,
He would have eaſe fain.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Mary I cannot blame him ſir.
But how he will come by't, there lyes the queſtion,

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: You muſt do ſomewhat ſir, for hee's ſwoln moſt piteouſly,
Has urine in him now was brew'd laſt March.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: 'Twill be rich geer for Dyers.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: I would 'twere come to that ſir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Le' me ſee, ile ſend him a whole Musket-charge of Gun-powder.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: Gun-powder? what ſir, to break the ſtone?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I by my faith ſir,
It is the likelieſt thing I know to do't,
I'm ſure it breaks ſtone-walls, and Caſtles down,
I ſee no reaſon, but't ſhould break the ſtone.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: Nay, uſe you pleaſure ſir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: 'Troth, if that doe not
I ha' nothing els that will.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: I know that too.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Why then thou'rt a Coxcomb to make queſtion on't.
Goe call in all the reſt, I have employment for them.
When the high-wayes grow thin with Travellers,
And few Portmantues ſtirring, as all trades
Have their dead time wee ſee; Thee very, poor takings,
And Lecherie cold doings, and ſo forwards ſtill;
Then doe I tak my Inn, and thoſe Curmoogions,
Whoſe Purſes I can never get abroad,
I take 'em at more eaſe here i' my chamber,
And make 'em come to me, it's more ſtate-like too:
Hang him that has but one way to his trade,
Hee's like a mouth that eats but on one ſide,
And half cozens his belly, ſpecially if he dine among Shavers,
sp.stage: Enter all the reſt Silvio, Stratio, Fiducio.
sp.l: And both-handed feeders: Stratio, Silvio, and Fiducio,
I will have none left out, there's parts for you.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: For us? pray let's have 'em.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Change your ſelves
With all ſpeed poſſible into ſeverall ſhapes
Far from your own, as you a Farmer ſir,
A Grazier you, and you may be a Miller.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Oh no, a Miller comes too neer a Theef,
That may ſpoil all agen.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Some Country Taylor then.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: That's neer enough by'r lady, yet Ile venture that;
The Miller's a white Devill, he wears his theft
Like Innocence in badges moſt apparently
Upon his noſe, ſometimes between his lips;
The Tailor modeſtly between his legs.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Why pray, do you preſent that modeſt thief then,
And hark you, for the purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: 'Twill improve you ſir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: 'Twill get believers, believe that my Maſters,
Repute and confidence, and make all things cleerer;
When you ſee any come, repair you to me
As ſamples of my skill; there are few arts
But have their ſhadows Sirs to ſet 'em off;
Then where the Art it ſelf is but a ſhadow
What need is there my Friends? make haſt away ſirs.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: Where are you Sir?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Not far man; What's the newes?

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: The old Juſtice ſir, whom we rob'd once by Moon-light,
And bound his man and he in haycock-time
With a rope made of horſe-meat, and in pittie
Left their Mares by 'em, which I think ere midnight
Did eat their hay-bound Maſters both at libertie,—

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: 'Life, what of him man?

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: Hee's enquiring earneſtly
For the great man of art; indeed for you ſir:
Therefore withdraw ſweet ſir; make your ſelf daintie now,
And that's three parts of any profeſſion.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I have enough on't.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: How now, what thing's this?
Now by this light, the ſecond part o'th' Juſtice
Newly reviv'd with never a hair on's face,
It ſhould be the firſt rather by his ſmoothneſs,
But I ha' known the firſt part written laſt:
'Tis he, or let me periſh, the young Gentleman
We robd, and ſtript, but I am far from knowledge now.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: One word I pray Sir.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: With me gentle Sir?

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: Was there not lately ſeen about theſe parts ſir
A knot of fellows, whoſe conditions
Are privily ſuſpected?

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: Why doe you ask Sir?

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: There was a poor young gentleman rob'd laſt night.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: Robd?

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: Script of all y'faith.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: Oh beaſtly Raſcals.
'Las what was he?

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: Look o'me, and know him ſir.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: Hard-hearted villains, ſtrip? troth when I ſaw you
Methought thoſe cloaths were never made for you ſir.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: Want made me glad o'em.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: 'Send you better fortunes ſir:
That we may have about with you once agen.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: I thank you for your wiſh of love, kind ſir.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: 'Tis with my heart y'faith; now ſtore of coyn
And better cloaths be with you.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: Ther's ſome honeſt yet
And charitably minded: how, wha'ts here to doe?
Here within this place is cur'd
All the griefs that were ev'r endur'd.
Nay there thou lyeſt, I endur'd one laſt night,
Thou canſt not cure this morning; a ſtrange Promiſer.
Palſey, Gout, Hydropick Humour,
Breath that ſticks beyond perſumer,
Fiſtula in ano, Ulcer, Megrum,
Or what diſeaſe ſo ere beleaguer 'em,
Stone, Rupture, Squinancie, Impoſthuma,
Yet too dear it ſhall not coſt 'em.
That's conſcionably ſaid y'faith.
In brief, you cannot I aſſure you
Be unſound ſo faſt, as I can cure you.
By'r Lady, you ſhall pardon me, ile not try't ſir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Martino, is not yond my hinder parts?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes, and your fore parts too Sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I tro ſo,
I never ſaw my hind parts in my life elſe,
No, nor my fore ones neither: what are you ſir?
Are you a Juſtice pray?

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: A Juſtice? no truly.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: How came this Suit to you then?

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: How, this Suit?
Why muſt he needs be a Juſtice ſir, that wears it?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: You'l find it ſo: 'twas made for no body elſe.
I pai'd for't.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: Oh ſtrange fortune, I have undone
The charitable woman.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Hee'l be gone.
Martino, hold him faſt, Ile call for aid.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: Hold me? oh curſs of fate!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Oh Mr, Mr.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: What ayls Martino?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: In my conſcience
Has beat out the wrong tooth, I feel it now,
Three degrees of.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Oh ſlave, ſpoild a fine Penman.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: He lackd good manners though: lay hands o' me?
I ſcorn all the deſerts, that belong to't.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Why how now? what's the broil?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: The man of art
I take you ſir to be.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I'm the profeſſor
Of thoſe ſlight cures you read of in the Banner.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Our buſineſs was to you moſt skilfull ſir,
But in the way to you, right worſhipfull
I met a thief.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: A thief?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: With my cloaths on ſir,
Let but the Hoſe be ſearcht, ile pawn my life
Ther's yet the Tailors bill in one o'th' pockets,
And a white thimble that I found i' moon light,
Thou ſawſt me when I put it in Martino.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Oy, oy.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Oh, has ſpoild the worthieſt Clark that ere drew Warrant here.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Sir, y'ar a ſtranger, but I muſt deal plain with you,
That Suit of cloaths muſt needs come odly to you.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: I dare not ſay which way, that's my affliction.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Is not your worſhips name Signior Brandino ſir?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: It has been ſo, theſe threeſcore year and upwards.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I heard there was a robbery done laſt night
Neer to your houſe.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: You heard a truth then ſir,
And I the man was robd.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Ah that's too groſs
Send him away for fear of farther miſchief,
I doe not like him, he's a cunning knave.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I want but aid.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Within there.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Ceize upon that impudent thief.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: Then here me ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Away;
Ile neither hear thee ſpeak, nor wear thoſe cloaths agen,
To priſon with the varlet.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: How am I puniſh'd?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Ile make thee bring out all, before I leave thee.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Y'have took an excellent courſe with this bold villain ſir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: I am ſworn for ſervice to the Common-wealth ſir,
sp.l: What are theſe, learned ſir?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Oh they'r my patients.
Good morrow, Gout, Rupture, and Palſie.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: 'Tis farewell Gout almoſt, I thank your worſhip.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What no, you cannot part ſo ſoon, I hope?
You came but lately to me.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: But moſt happily,
I can goe neer to leap ſir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What you cannot?
Away I ſay, take heed, be not to ventrous though,
I've had you but three daies, remember that.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Thoſe three are better than three hundred ſir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Yet agen?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Eaſe takes pleaſure to be known ſir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: You with the rupture there hernia in ſcrotum.
Pray let me ſee your ſpace this morning, walk ſir,
Ile take your diſtance ſtrait: 'twas F. O. yeſterday:
Ah ſirha, here's a ſimple alteration,
Secundo gradu, ye F. U. already,
Here's a moſt happy change; be of good comfort ſir,
Your knees are come, within three inches now
Of one an other; by to morrow noon
Ile make'em kiſs, and juſtle.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: 'Bleſs your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: You have a hundred pray'rs in a morning ſir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: 'Faith we have a few to paſs away the day with:
Taylor, you had a ſtitch.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Oh good your worſhip
I have had none ſince Eaſter: were I rid
But of this whorſon Palſey, I were happy;
I cannot thred my needle.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: No, that's hard,
I never markt ſo much.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: It comes by fits ſir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: 'Las poor man: what would your worſhip ſay now
To ſee me help this fellow at an inſtant?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: And make him firm from ſhaking?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: As a ſteeple,
From the diſeaſe on't.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: 'Tis to me miraculous.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: You, with your whoremaſter diſeaſe, come hither;
Here, take me this round glaſs, and hold it ſtedfaſt,
Yet more ſir, yet I ſay; ſo.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Admirable.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Goe, live, and thred thy needle.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Here Martino:
'Las poor Fool, his mouth is full of praiſes
And cannot utter 'em.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: No, what's the malady?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: The fury of a tooth.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: A tooth? ha, ha,
I though't had been ſome Gangrene, Fiſtula,
Canker, or Ramex.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: No, 'its enough as 'tis ſir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: My man ſhall eaſe that ſtreight, ſit you down there ſir,
Take the tooth ſirha, daintily, inſenſibly:
But what's your worſhips malady, that's for me ſir?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Marry pray look you ſir: your worſhips Counſell
About mine eyes.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Sore eyes? that's nothing too ſir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: By'r Lady I that fell it▪ think it ſomewhat.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Have you no Convulſions? pricking aches ſir,
Ruptures, or Apoſtemates?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: No by my faith ſir,
Not doe I deſire to have 'em.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Thoſe are •• res,
There doe I win my fame ſir: quickly ſirrah,
Reach me the eye-cup hither: doe you make water well ſir?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I'm all well there.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: You feel no grief i'th' kidney.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Sound, ſound, ſound ſir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Oh here's a breath ſir, I muſt talk withall
One of theſe mornings.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: There I think y'faith,
I am to blame indeed, and my Wiſes words
Are come to paſſe ſir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Oh, oh, 'tis not that, 'tis not that.
It is the next beyond it; there, there, there.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: The beſt have their miſtakings: now Ile fit you ſir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: What's that ſweet Sir, that comforts with his coolneſs?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Oh ſoverign geer: wink hard, and keep it in ſir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Oh, oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: Nay, here he goes, one twitch more, and he comes ſir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Auh, ho.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: Spit out▪ I told you he was gone ſir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: How cheers Martino?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Oh, I can anſwer you now Maſter,
I feel great eaſe ſir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: So doe I Martino.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I'm rid of a ſore burden, for my part Maſter,
Of a ſcal'd little one.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Pleaſe but your worſhip now
To take three drops of the rich water with you,
Ile undertake your man ſhall cure you ſir
At twice i'your own Chamber.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Shall he ſo ſir?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I will uphold him in't.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Then will I do't ſir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: How lively your man's now?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Oh I'm ſo light me thinks
Over I was.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: What i • 't contents your worſhip?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Ev'n what your worſhip pleaſe, I am not mercenary.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: My purſe is gone Martino.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: How, your purſe ſir?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: 'Tis gon y'faith: I'ave been among ſome Raſcalls.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And that's a thing
I ever gave you warning of Maſter, you care not
What company you run into.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Lend me ſome money: chide me anon I pre' thee.
A pox on 'em for vipers, they ha'ſuckt blood o'me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Oh Maſter.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: How now man?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My purſe is gon too.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: How? Ile never take warning more of thee while I live then, thou art an Hypocrite, and art not fit to give good counſell to thy Maſter, that canſt not keep from ill company thy ſelf.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: This is moſt ſtrange ſir: both your purſes gon.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sir, I'de my hand on mine, when I came in.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Are you but ſure of that; oh would you were.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: As I'm of eaſe.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Then, they'r both gon one way, be that your comfort.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I but what way's that ſir?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: That cloſe knave in your Clothes h'as got 'em both,
'Tis well y'have clapt him faſt.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Why that's impoſſible.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Oh tell not me ſir: I ha' known purſes gon,
And the Theef ſtand, and look one full i'th' face,
As I may doe your Worſhip, and your man now.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Nay, that's moſt certain Maſter.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I will make
That Raſcall in my clothes anſwer all this then,
And all the robberies that have been don
Since the Moon chang'd; get you home firſt Martino,
And know if any of my wives things are miſſing,
Or any more of mine: tell her hee's taken,
And by that token he has took both our purſes.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: That's an ill token Maſter.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: That's all one ſir,
She muſt have that or nothing, for I'm ſure
The Raſcall has left nothing els for a Token.
Begon, make haſt agen; and meet me part o'th' way.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Ile hang the villain,
And 't were for nothing but the Sowce he gave me.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Sir, I depart aſham'd of my requitall,
And leave this ſeal ring with you as a pledge
Of further thankfulneſs.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: No, I beſeech you ſir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Indeed you ſhall ſir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Oh, your worſhips word ſir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: You ſhall have my word too, for a rare gedtleman
As ere I met withall.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Cleer ſight be with you ſir;
If Conduit-water, and my Hoſteſſe Milk
That comes with the ninth child now, may afford it.
'Life, I fear'd none but thee, my villanous toothdrawer,

sp.speaker: Occult.
sp.l: There was no fear of me; I've often told you
I was bound Prentice to a Barber once,
But ran away i'th' ſecond year.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I marry,
That made thee give a pull at the wrong tooth.
And me afraid of thee: what have we there ſirs?

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: Some threeſcore Dollars i'th Maſters purſe,
And ſixteen in the Clerks, a Silver ſeal,
Two or three Amber beads, and four blank Warrants.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Warrants? where be they? the beſt news came yet.
'Maſſe here's his hand, and here's his Seal I thank him,
This comes moſt luckily: one of our fellows
Was took laſt night, wee'l ſet him firſt at libertie,
And other good Boyes after him: and if he
In th' old Juſtices Suit, whom he rob'd lately,
Will come off roundly, wee'l ſet him free too.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: That were a good deed 'faith, we may in pitty.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: There's nothing done meerly for pitty now adaies,
Money or Ware muſt help too.

div.stage: Song, in parts by the Thieves.

lg.l: Give me fortune, give me health,
Give me freedome, Ile get wealth.
When he has the wide world his?
He that has the Devill in fee,
Can have but all, and ſo have wee.
Give us fortune, give us Health,
Give us freedome, wee'l get wealth.
In every Hamlet, Town and Cittie,
He has lands, that was born wittie.

div.head: Actus 5. Scaena 1.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: HOw well this Gentleman keeps his promiſe too?
Sure there's no truſt in man.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: They'r all Franciſco's,
That's my opinion Miſtris: Fools, or falſe ones.
He might have had the honeſtie yet y'faith
To ſend my Maſters clothes home.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I thoſe clothes.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Collyers come by the dore ev'ry day Miſtris,
Nay, this is Market-day too, Powlterers, Butchers,
They would have lay'n moſt deintily in a Panyer,
And kept Veal from the wind.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Thoſe clothes much trouble me.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: 'Faith, and he were a gentleman as he ſeem'd to be,
They would trouble him too I think;
Me thinks he ſhould have ſmall deſire to keep 'em.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'Faith and leſſe pride to wear'em, I ſhould think wench,
Unleſſe he kept'em as a teſtimonie
For after-times to ſhew what miſetie
He paſt in his young dayes, and then weep over 'em.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Weep Miſtris? nay ſure me thinks he ſhould not weep for laughing.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Martino? oh w'are ſpolld wench, are they come then?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Miſtris, be of good cheer, I have excellent news for you, comfort your heart, what have you to breakfaſt Miſtris, you ſhall have all agen, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What ſaies he Wench?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I'm loth to underſtand him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Give me a note of all your things ſweet Miſtris,
You ſhall not loſe a hair, take't of my word
We have him ſafe enough.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Olas, ſweet wench
This man talks fearfully.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: And I know not what yet
That's the worſt Miſtriſs.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Can you tell me pray,
Whether the Raſcall has broke ope my desk or no,
Ther's a fine little barrell of pom-citrons
Would have ſerv'd me this ſeven year, oh, and my fig-cheeſe.
The fig of everlaſting obloquy
Goe with him if he have eat it, Ile make haſte
He cannot eat it all yet, he was taken Miſtriſs
Groſly, and beaſtly, how doe you think y'faith?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I know not ſir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Troth in my Maſters cloaths,
Would any thief but a beaſt been taken ſo?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Wench, wench.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I have grief enough of mine own to tend Miſtriſs.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Did he confeſs the robbery?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O no, no Miſtriſs
He's a young cunning Raſcall, he confeſt nothing;
While we were examining on him, he took away
My Maſters purſs and mine, but confeſt nothing ſtill.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: That's but ſome ſlanderous injury rais'd againſt him.
Came not your Mr. with you?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No ſweet Miſtriſs.
I muſt make haſt and meet him pray diſpatch me then.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I have lookd over all with ſpeciall heedfulneſs,
Ther's nothing miſs'd, I can aſſure you ſir
But that Suit of your Maſters.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I'm right glad on't That Suit would hang him yet I would not have him hangd in that Suit though, it will diſgrace my Maſters faſhion for ever, and make it as hatefull as yellow bands.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: O what ſhall's doe wench?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: 'Tis no marvail Miſtriſs
The poor young Gentleman could not keep his promiſe.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'Alas ſweet man, h'as confeſs'd nothing yee wench.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: That ſhews his conſtancy, and love to you Miſtriſs:
But you muſt do't of force, there is no help for't,
The truth can neither ſhame nor hurt you much,
Let 'em make what they can on't, 'twere ſin and pitty y'faith
To caſt away ſo ſweet a Gentleman,
For ſuch a pair of infidell hoſe and doublet,
I would not hang a Jew for a whole wardrobe on 'em.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Thou ſaiſt true wench.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Oh, oh, they'r come agen Miſtriſs.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Signior Anſaldo?

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: The ſame mightily croſs'd Lady,
But paſt hope freed agen by a Doctors means,
A man of art, I know not juſtly what indeed,
But pitty, and the fortunate gold you gave me,
Wrought my releaſe between 'em.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Met you not
My husbands man?

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: I took ſuch ſtrange wayes Lady
I hardly met a creature.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Oh moſt welcome

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: But how ſhall we beſtow him now we have him Mris?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'Alas, that's true.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Martino may come back agen.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Step you into that little Chamber ſpeedily ſir,
And dreſs him up in one of my Gowns and head-tyres
His youth will well endure it.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: That wilbe admirable.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nay do't, do't quickly then, and cut that Suit
Into a hundred pieces, that it may never be known agen.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: A hundreth? nay ten thouſand at the leaſt Mris.
For if there be a piece of that Suit left, as big as my nail,
The deed will come out, 'tis worſe than a murder,
I fear 'twill never be hid.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Away, do your endeavour, and diſpatch wench,
I've thought upon a way of certain ſafetie,
And I may keep him while I have him too,
Without ſuſpition now: I've heard o'th' like:
A Gentleman, that for a Ladies love
Was thought ſix months her woman, tended on her
In her own garments, and ſhe being a Widow,
Lay night by night with her in way of comfort,
Mary in concluſion match they did together,
Would I'd a copy of the ſame concluſion:
He's come himſelf now, if thou be'ſt a happy wench
Be fortunate in thy ſpeed, Ile delay time
With all the means I can: oh welcome ſir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Ile ſpeak to you anon wife, and kiſs you ſhortly,
I'm very buſie yet: Cockſey-down, Mem-berrie,
Her Manner houſe at Well-dun.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What's that good ſir?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: The widows your ſweet Siſters deed of gift;
Sh'as made all her eſtate over to me wench:
She'l be too hard for 'em all: and now come buſs me
Good luck after thieves hanſell.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Oh 'tis happy Sir
You have him faſt.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I ha' laid him ſafe enough wench.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I was ſo loſt in joy at the report on't
I quight forgot one thing to tell Martino.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: What's that ſweet blood?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: He, and his villains ſir
Robd a ſweet Gentlewoman laſt night.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: A Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nay, moſt uncivilly and baſely ſtript her ſir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Oh barbarous ſlaves.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I was ev'n fain for woman-hoods ſake
(Alas) and charities, to receive her in,
And cloath her poor wants in a Suit of mine.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: 'Twas moſt religiouſly done: I long for her;
Who have I brought to ſee thee think'ſt thou woman?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nay Sir, I know not.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Gheſs, I prethee heartily:
An enemy of thine.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: That I hope you have not ſir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: But all was done in jeſt: he crys thee mercy,
Franciſco ſirha.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Oh; I think not on him.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: That Letter was but writ to try thy conſtancie,
He confeſt all to me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Joy on him ſir, [Enter Franciſco.]
So far am I from malice, look you ſir;
Welcome ſweet Signior; but Ile never truſt you ſir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Faith I'm beholding to thee wife, for this.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Methinks, I enter now this houſe with joy,
Sweet peace, and quietneſs of conſcience,
I wear no guilty bluſh upon my cheek
For a ſin ſtampt laſt midnight: I can talk now
With that kind man, and not abuſe him inwardly,
With any ſcornfull thought made of his ſhame:
What a ſweet being is an honeſt mind?
It ſpeaks peace to itſelf, and all mankind.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Martino.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Maſter.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Ther's an other robbery done ſirha,
By the ſame partie.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What? your worſhip mocks,
Under correction.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I forgot to tell thee
He robd a lovely Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O Pagan,
This fellow will be ſton'd to death with Pipkins,
Your women in the Suburbs will ſo maule him
With broken crew • es, and pitchers without eares,
He will nev'r dye alive, that's my opinion.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Look you your judgments Gentlemen, yours eſpecially
Signior Franciſco, whoſe meer object now
Is woman at theſe years, that's the eye Saint I know
Amongſt young Gallants, Husband, you have a glimpſe too;
You offer half an eye, as old as you are,

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: By'r Lady better wench: an eye, and a half I troa,
I ſhould be ſorry elſe.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What think you now ſirs
Is't not a goodly manly Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Beſhew my heart elſe wife.
Pray ſoft a little Signior y'ar but my gueſt remember,
I'm Mr. of the houſe, Ile have the firſt buſs.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: But Husband, 'tis the curteſie of all places
To give a ſtranger ever the firſt bit.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: In Woodcock or ſo, but ther's no heed to be taken in Mutton;
We commonly fall ſo roundly to that we forget our ſelves:
I'm ſorry for thy fortune, but thou'it welcome Lady

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: My Maſter kiſſes, as I've heard a hackney man Cheer up his Mare, chap, chap.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I have him faſt Lady, and he ſhall lye by't cloſe,

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: You cannot doe me a greater pleaſure Sir,

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I'm happily glad on't.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Me thinks there's ſomewhat whiſpers in my ſoul,
This is the hour, I muſt begin my acquaintance
With honeſt love, and baniſh all looſe thoughts;
My fate ſpeaks to me from the modeſt eye
Of yon ſweet Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Wench, Wench.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Piſh, hold in your breath Miſtris,
If you be ſeen to laugh, you ſpoil all preſently,
I keep it in with all the might I have—puh.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: Pray what young gentleman's that ſir?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: An honeſt boy y'faith,
And came of a good kind: do'ſt like him Lady,
I would thou hadſt him, and thou beeſt not promis'd,
Hee's worth ten thouſand Dollars.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: By this light Miſtris, my Maſter will goe neer to make a match anon, me thinks I dream of admirable ſport Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Peace, thou art a drab.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Come hither now Franciſco,
I've know the time, I've had a better ſtomach;
Now I can dine with looking upon meat.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: That face deſerv'd a better fortune Lady
Than laſt nights rudeneſs ſhew'd.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: We cannot be
Our chooſers ſir in our own deſteny.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I return better pleas'd, than when I went.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And could that beaſtly Impe rob you forſooth?

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: Moſt true forſooth,
I will not altogether ſir, diſgrace you,
Becauſe you look half like a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And that's the Mothers half.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: There's my hand for you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I ſwear you could not give me any thing
I love better, a hand gets me my living;
Oh ſweet lymon-peel.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: May I requeſt a modeſt word or two Lady
In private with you?

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: With me ſir?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: To make it ſure from all ſuſpect of injurie,
Or unbeſeeming private, which heaven knows
Is not my aym now, Ile intreat this gentleman
For an ear witneſs unto all our conference.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: Why ſo, I am content Sir,

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: So am I Lady..

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Oh Maſter, here's a rare Bedfellow for my Miſtris to night,
For you know we muſt both out of Town agen.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: That's true Martino.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I do but think how they'l lye telling of tales together
The pretieſt.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: The pretilieſt indeed.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Their tongues will never lyn wagging Maſter.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Never Martino, never.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Take heed you be not heard.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I fear you moſt Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Mee fool? ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Why look you Miſtris: faith y'are faultie, ha, ha,

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Well ſaid y'faith, where lyes the fault now goſſip.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Oh for a husband; I ſhall burſt with laughing els,
This houſe is able to ſpoil any Maid.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Ile be reveng'd now ſoundly of Franciſco
For failing me when time was.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Are you there Miſtris? I thought you would not forget that
How ever, a good turn diſappointed is ever the laſt thing
That a woman forgives, ſhee'l ſcarce do't when ſhee's ſpeechleſs,
Nay, though ſhe hold up her whole hand for all other injuries,
Shee'l forgive that but with one finger.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Ile vex his heart as much as he mock'd mine.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: But that may marre your hopes too, if our gentlewoman be known to be a man.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Not as Ile work it;
I would not loſe this ſweet revenge me thinks
For a whole fortnight of the old mans abſence,
Which is the ſweeteſt benefit next to this:
Why how now ſir, what courſe take you for laughing?
We are undone for one.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: Faith with great pain,
Stifle it, and keep it in: I ha' no receipe for't.
But 'pray, in ſadneſs ſay; What is the Gentleman,
I never knew his like for tedious urgings,
He will receive no anſwer.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Would he would not Sir.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: Sayes I'm ordain'd for him: meerly for him,
And that his wiving fate ſpeaks in me to him;
Will force on me a joynture ſpeedily
Of ſome ſeven thouſand Dollars.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Would thou had'ſt'em ſir: I know he can and he will.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: For wonders pitty; What is this Genleman?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'Faith ſhall I tell you ſir,
One that would make an excellent honeſt husband
For her that's a juſt Maid at one and twentie;
For on my conſcience he has his Maidenhead yet.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: Fye, out upon him beaſt.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Sir, if you love me.
Give way but to one thing I ſhall requeſt of you.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: Your curteſies you know may lay commands on me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Then at his next ſollicitings, let a conſent
Seem to come from you; 'Twill make noble ſport ſir,
Wee'll get joincture and all; but you muſt bear
Your ſelf moſt affable to all his purpoſes.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: I can doe that.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I, and take head of laughing.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: I've bide the worſt of that already Lady.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Peace, ſet your countenance then; for here he comes.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: There is no middle continent in this paſſion,
I feel it ſince, it muſt be love, or death
It was ordain'd for one.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Seignior Franciſco,
I'm ſorry 'twas your fortune, in my houſe ſir,
To have ſo violent a ſtroak come to you:
The gentlewoman's a ſtranger pray be counſell'd ſir,
Till you hear further of her Friends and portion.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: 'Tis only but her love that I deſire,
She comes moſt rich in that.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: But be advis'd though,
I think ſhee's rich heir, but ſee the proof ſir,
Before you make her ſuch a generous Jointure.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: 'Tis mine, and I will doo't.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: She ſhalbe yours too,
If I may rule her then.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: You ſpeak all ſweetneſs.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: She likes your perſon well, I tell you ſo much,
But take no note I ſaid ſo.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Not a word.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Come Lady, come, the gentleman deſertfull,
And O my conſcience honeſt.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: Blame me not, I am a Maid, and fearfull.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Never truth came perfecter from man.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Give her a lip-taſte,
That ſhe her ſelf may praiſe it.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Yea, a match y'faith: my houſe is luckly for 'em
Now Martino.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Maſter, the Widow has the day.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: The day?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: She's overthrown my youngſter.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Pretious tydings,
Clap down four Woodcocks more.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: They'r all at hand Sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: What both her adverſaries too.

div.stage: Enter Valeria, Ricardo, and two Suters.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: They'r come ſir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: God bid the Cook ſerve in two geeſe in a diſh.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I like your conceit Maſter beyond utterance.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: VVelcome ſweet Siſter; which is the man muſt have you.
Ide welcome no body els.

sp.speaker: 1 Suter.
sp.l: Come to me then ſir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Are yo' he' faith, my chain of gold? I'm glad on't.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I wonder you can have the face to follow me,
That have ſo proſecuted things againſt me,
But I ha' reſolv'd my ſelf 'tis done to ſpight me.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: O dearth of truth.

sp.speaker: 2 Suter.
sp.l: Nay, do not ſpoil thy hair,
Hold, hold I ſay, Ile get thee a VVidow ſomewhere.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: If hand and faith be nothing for a Contract,
VVhat ſhall man hope?

sp.speaker: 2 Suter.
sp.l: 'Twas wont to be enough, Honey.
When there was honeſt meaning amongſt Widows,
But ſince your bribes came in, 'tis not allow'd
A contract without gifts to bind it faſt,
Every thing now muſt have a feeling firſt:
Doe I come neer you Widow?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No indeed ſir,
Nor ever ſhall I hope: and for your comfort ſir,
That ſought all means t'entrap me for my wealth,
Had Law unfortunately put you upon me,
You had loſt your labour, all your aym, and hopes ſir:
Here ſtands the honeſt Gentleman my Brother
To whom I've made a deed of gift of all.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I that ſheh' as y'faith, I thank her Gentlemen
Look you here ſirs.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I muſt not look for pleaſures
That give more grief if they prove falſe, or fail us
Then ever they gave joy.

sp.speaker: 1 Suter.
sp.l: Ha'you ſe've me ſo widow

sp.speaker: 2 Suter.
sp.l: I'm glad thou haſt her not, laugh at him honey; ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I muſt take one that loves me for my ſelf:
Here's as old Gentleman looks not after wealth
But vertue, manners, and conditions.

sp.speaker: 1 Suter.
sp.l: Yes by my faith: I muſt have Lordſhips too Widow.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: How ſir?

sp.speaker: 1 Suter.
sp.l: Your manners, vertue, and conditions Widow.
Are prety things within dores, I like well on 'em,
But I muſt have ſomewhat with out-lying or being
In the tenure or occupation of me ſuch a one: ha?
Thoſe are fine things indeed.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why ſir, you ſwore to me it was for love.

sp.speaker: 1 Suter.
sp.l: True; but thers two words to a bargain ever
All the world over, and if love be one
I'm ſure mony's the other; 'tis no bargain elſe:
Pardon me, I muſt dine, as well as ſup Widow.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Cry mercy, I miſtook you all this while ſir.
It was this antient Gentleman indeed,
Whom I crave pardon on.

sp.speaker: 2 Suter.
sp.l: What of me Widow?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'Alas I have wrongd you ſir; 'twas you that ſwore
You lov'd me for my ſelf?

sp.speaker: 2 Suter.
sp.l: By my troth but I did not.
Come, Father not your lyes upon me Widow:
I love you for your ſelf? ſpit at me Gentlemen
If ever I'd ſuch a thought, fetch me in Widow:
You'l find your reach too ſhort.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why you have enough you ſay.

sp.speaker: 2 Suter.
sp.p: I, but I will have my humour too; you never think of that, they'r Coach horſes, they goe together ſtill.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Whom ſhould a Widow truſt: I'l ſwear 'twas one of you
That made me beleeve ſo: maſs, think 'twas you ſir
Now I remember me.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I ſwore too much
To be beleev'd ſo little.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Was it you then?
Beſhrew my heart for wronging of you.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Welcome bleſſing,
Are you nine faithfully now?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: As love can make one.

sp.speaker: 1 Suter.
sp.l: Why this fils the Common-wealth ſo full of beggars,
Marrying for love, which none of mine ſhall doe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But now I think on't: we muſt part agen ſir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Agen?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You'r in debt, and I, in doubt of all,
Left my ſelf nothing too; we muſt not hold,
Want on both ſides makes all affection cold:
I ſhall not keep you from that Gentleman,
You'l be his more then mine and when he liſt
He'l make you lye from me in ſome ſoure priſon,
Then let him take you now for altogether ſir,
For he that's mine ſhall be all mine or nothing.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I never felt the evill of my debts
Till this afflicting minute.

sp.speaker: 2 Suter.
sp.p: Ile be mad once in my daies: I have enough to cure me, and I will have my humour, they'r now but deſperate debts agen, I nev'r look for 'em,
sp.l: And ever ſince I knew what malice was
I alwaies held it ſweeter to ſow miſchief.
Than to receive money; 'tis the finer pleaſure.
Ile give him in his bonds as 'twere in pitty
To make the match, and bring 'em both to beggary,
Then will they nev'r agree; that's a ſure point,
He'l give her a black eye within theſe three daies,
Beat half her teeth out by Alhall outide,
And break the little houſhold-ſtuffe they have
With throwing at one another: O ſweet ſport.
Come Widow, come, ile try your honeſtie
Here to my honey y'have made many proffers,
I fear they'r all but tricks: here are his debts Gentlemen:
How I came by 'em I know beſt my ſelf.
Take him before us faithfully for your husband
And he ſhall tear 'em all before your face Widow.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Elſe may all faith refuſe me:

sp.speaker: 2 Suter.
sp.l: Tear 'em honey
'Tis firm in Law, a conſideration given:
What with thy teeth? thoul't ſhortly tear her ſo
That's all my hope, thoud'ſt never had 'em elſe
I've enough, and I will have my humour.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I'm now at liberty Widow.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ile be ſo too
And then I come to thee: give me this from you Brother,

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Hold Siſter: Siſter.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Look you, the deed of gift ſir, I'm as free
He that has me, has all, and thou art he.
1. 2. How's that?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Y'ar bob'd, 'twas but a deed in truſt
And all to prove thee, whom I have found moſt juſt.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I'm bob'd among the reſt too: I'd have ſworn
T'had been a thing for me, and my heirs for ever;
If I'd but got it up to the black box above
I had been paſt redemption

sp.speaker: 1 Suter.
sp.l: How am I cheated?

sp.speaker: 2 Suter.
sp.l: I hope you'l have the conſcience now to pay me ſir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Oh wicked man, ſower of ſtrife and envy, open not thy lips.

sp.speaker: 2 Suter.
sp.l: How, how's this?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Thou haſt no charge at all, no child of thine own
But two thou got'ſt once of a ſcowring woman,
And they are both well provided for, thei'r i'th hoſpitall,
Thou haſt ten thouſand pound to bury thee,
Hang thy ſelf when thou wilt, a ſlave goe with thee

sp.speaker: 2 Suter.
sp.l: I'm gone, my goodneſs comes all out together.
I have enough, but I have not my humour.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: O Maſter, Gentlemen: and you ſweet Widow
I think you are no forwarder yet, I know not,
If ever you be ſure to laugh agen,
Now is the time.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why what's the matter wench?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Speak, ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Ha, a marriage, a marriage, I cannot tel't for laughing: ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: A marriage doe you make that a laughing matter?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Ha: I, and you'l make it ſo when you know all,
Here they come, here they come, one man married to an other.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: How? man to man?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I man to man y'faith
Ther'l be good ſport at night to bring 'em both to bed;
Doe you ſee 'em now, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: 1 Suter.
sp.l: My daughter Martia.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: Oh my Father: your love, and pardon ſir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'Tis ſhe indeed Getlemen.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: I have been diſobedient I confeſs
Unto your mind, and Heaven has puniſhed me
With much affliction ſince I fled your ſight;
But finding reconcilement from above
In peace of heart; the next I hopes your love.

sp.speaker: 1 Suter.
sp.l: I cannot but forgive thee now I ſee thee,
Thou fledſt a happy fortune of an old man,
But Franciſco's of a noble family.
Though he be ſomewhat ſpent.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I lov'd her not ſir
As ſhe was yours, for I proteſt I knew't not,
But for her ſelf ſir, and her own deſerving,
Which had you been as foul, as y'ave been ſpightfull
I ſhould have lov'd in her.

sp.speaker: 1 Suter.
sp.l: Well, hold your prating ſir,
Y'ar not like to looſe by't.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Oh Violetta, who ſhall laugh at us now?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: The child unborn Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: Be good.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Be honeſt.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: Heav'n will not let you ſin, and you'ld be carefull.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: What means it ſends to help you, think and mend,
You'r as much bound as we, to praiſe that frend.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I am ſo, and I will ſo.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: Marry you ſpeedily,
Children tame you, you'l die like a wild beaſt els.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I by my troth ſhould I, I've much adoe to forbear
Laughing now, more's my hard fortune.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O Maſter, Miſtris, and you gentles all;
To horſe, to horſe preſently, if you mean to doe your Country any ſervice.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Art not aſham'd Martino, to talk of horſing ſo openly
Before young married couples thus.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It do's concern the Common-wealth and me,
And you Maſter, and all: the Theeves are taken.

sp.speaker: Anſ.
sp.l: What ſai'ſt Martino,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Law, here's Common-wealths-men,
The man of art Maſter, that cupt your eyes
Is prov'd an arrant raſcall: and his man
That drew my tooth, an excellent purſe-drawer,
I felt no pain in that, it went inſenſibly:
Such notable villanies confeſt.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Stop there ſir:
Wee'l have time for them: Come gentle-folks,
Take a ſlight meal with us: but the beſt cheer
Is perfect joy, and that we wiſh all here.—

div.head: Prologue.
div.l: A Sport, only for Chriſtmas, is the Play
This hour preſents t' you; to make you merry,
Is all th' ambition 'thas; and fulleſt aym
Bent at your ſmiles, to win it ſelf a name:
And if you edge be not quite taken off,
Wearied with ſports, I hope 'twill make you laugh.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: STay, ſtay, Sir, I'm as hungry of my Widdow
As you can be upon your Maid beleeve it,
But we muſt come to our deſires in order,
There's duties to be paid, e'r we goe further;
Hee that without your likings, leaves this place,
Is like one falls to meat, and forgets grace.
And that's not hanſome truſt me, no,
Our rights being paid, and your loves underſtood,
My Widow, and my meat, then do's me good;
I ha' no money Wench, I told thee true,
For my report, pray let her hear't from you,
